In addition,  when my oldest was experiencing some behavioral challenges, the teachers and administration all worked with me to develop a plan that best suited my child's needs. 

Can't say enough about this place. Pop in for a tour. Tell them Jenn D sent you.

review.author: Jessica O.
review.description:
We moved my daughter to Briarwood Child Academy a little over a year ago.  It was the best decision we could have made for her.  She went from being extremely shy with a distaste for going to "school" to a child who is excited every day to go see her friends and teachers.  She has improved both academically and socially.  

Her teachers as well as the other staff at Briarwood have always made themselves available to discuss any concerns I have had or to answer my questions.

Even when we moved away from North Smithfield, we kept our daughter at Briarwood.  I just can't imagine moving her away from somewhere that we love so much.

review.author: Christina G.
review.description:
Don't do it, please find another place. They are ok at best and your kid deserves better, it's in a plaza with a gym so the parking is horrendous, the security is poor as everyone allows piggybacking and there's not always an employee near the entrance to notice, and the gross motor room has a dangerous 2-story slide meant for older kids that I've seen kids sneak past the foam barricade to get to. 

We started sending our son after a trusted recommendation; they've since removed their child from attendance and have apologized profusely to us. I'd say I'm surprised to see the positive reviews but I'm not, there was a big hoopla about the great prizes you could win if you posted a positive review on Yelp in October and November, even with email reminders. 

We were given a tour and weren't entirely sold on the place, the teachers dressed like teenagers and did not inspire confidence and the rooms seemed so small, but again we had a trusted recommendation. Our son joined the toddler program. I quickly noticed he was moved from toddler rooms frequently as I'd have to hunt in other classrooms for him at pickup; I did not like the inconsistent teacher/room relationship but this is how they balance the child/teacher ratio - bouncing. They send home a daily sheet for your child, usually, however you cant rely on it we learned. You'll notice it's often a form that's been filled out once and photo copied with names hand written later. I noticed it was inaccurate at times; one time for the lunch it was handwritten that my son ate the snack brought from home - except we did not send him with a snack so who's form did we have? Speaking of food, my son is a picky eater. We supplemented his last daycares menu with snacks but were quickly told not to because he ate fine, despite always being very hungry at pickup. I should've paid more attention there. The meals arent really nutritious, more like what an Uncle might serve. Our son moved into the preschool program. At first we were happy, he suddenly seemed to enjoy going everyday and we actually saw the teachers teaching, not just supervising. A teacher talked to us about his communication, he's behind there, and encouraged us to get speech therapy; wow she notices and cares we think. A teacher says our son hardly eats anything they give him so we start sending snacks, that go unused so we dont believe they were offered. We notice the gross motor room change, it's slammed pack with preschoolers and very chaotic. Turns out they put all the preschoolers together while reducing the number of teachers (as the law allows) whereas toddlers was done in smaller groups of kids. My son was not prepared for this and found it too loud and too active for his comfort, reacting poorly to provocation and an occasional biting problem became regular. The incident reports are poorly done, lacking detail sometimes lacking entire sections. The teachers would tell us a whole story at pickup and it was disappointing that those details werent documented. Just recently we were verbally told that he reacted to being kicked by another child but we were not given an injury report to sign because biting was more severe. 

We were concerned parents, we started reading books to him about biting and even supplied the school with copies as they had no such literature, we talked to him about it at length, and we did not have a biting problem with him at home or with friends/family. We told the teachers please call us if he's having a bad day, we'd rather pick him up early than have a problem persist; never called. We suggested picking him up before gross motor time to avoid the situation but teachers advised against it, that he'd adjust in time. We asked several times if this repeat behavior was severe enough to have him "disenrolled" and every time told that we'd be advised well ahead of time and we werent near that happening (as recently as last week we were told). What a relief, our second child is due in 2 weeks and who'd want disenrollment sprang on them then right? Except that's what they did today, he did have another incident today. Just like that, no notice or warning, not even a hint from a teacher that the problem was actually severe or action was imminent. I think that's what bothered me the most. Until the emotional reaction subsided and I thought about how we've already started the search to find him a new preschool anyways, they just upped the timeline. We do know we're better off not sending our son there, the flags were obvious.

review.author: Julia B.
review.description: Our daughter Layla loves this place! We, as parents, are very pleased as well. The toddler teachers are truly awesome! The owner & vice president are really great as well. \nWe visited a lot of day cares/academies prior to signing up and are very happy, that we chose Briarwood Child Academy!

review.author: Dee B.
review.description:
My 3 year old and 15 month old go to Briarwood and we all love it! The skills they are able to learn here are things we wouldn't be able to teach them at home. My 15 month old is more than happy to go to his Infant room in the morning and play with the other babies. They work on letters and colors and shapes, adorable art projects, as well as music and movement, and he has developed so much and learned so much thanks to the many teachers working with him there. 

My 3 year old learns so much in the preschool class as well! He has learned things like sign language, yoga, Spanish, authors, countries, and I really like how each week and each month has a different theme that the lessons are based on so parents can follow along at home. On top of that they reinforce the basics of letters, numbers, counting, music, reading, etc, and again, they do the best art projects!

I also really like how for both kids play and outdoor activity is built into every day. They have really great outdoor play areas for different age groups, a splash park for summer, and a large indoor gross motor/play room for bad weather. On top of all that the meals that are included are healthy and well rounded and suitable for even the younger babies. And all of the teachers that I have met there are so nice, and so patient. I was also very impressed that even just after a month of going teachers I had never seen knew my sons' names and would greet them in the halls as we would come in or out. You can tell the teachers there really care about the kids. We have been nothing but happy with Briarwood for both my infant and preschooler!

review.author: Steve B.
review.description: Do your child a favor and stay far away. We should have left when one of their teachers physically and verbally assaulted my child. We were convinced to stay by their owner and it was a mistake. After being told by her teacher that she was one of the children that she did not have to worry about, she was transferred to a new class with a teacher who I can only assume is not able to do her job. All of the friends she had in class were put in one class and she was put in another.This is when we were told that she had become such a problem they abandoned her and kicked her out within 2 weeks. This was after we were given a phone number to call by the director for children who are acting out and to help them cope. Turns out it was for children that have been diagnosed with Mental Disorders. Excuse me! They do not know how to handle children. They go through directors like toilet paper and the director they have now is in over her head. I have spoken with former staff members since and they have told me how bad the school actually was and that we are lucky to no longer be there. Keep your kids away.

review.author: Danielle R.
review.description: Briarwood is such an inviting place.  Our son is almost 3 and has been going there for 2 years.  I can't say thank you enough to the teachers he's had in both the infant and toddler room.  When he first started in the infant room he would cry at drop off, which is obviously hard for a parent.  It made it easier when I saw them embracing and snuggling him.  He also has asthma and they are very attentive to his needs.  He used to need a nebulizer and they were well educated on how to use it and noted if they did use it on his daily sheet.  I also love their curriculum.  My son came home and I overheard him saying his numbers in Spanish and that wasn't something we had gone over.  They have music, culinary, and gym class weekly.  The director is also amazing.  You walk in the door and she greets each adult and child by name.  She is also in the classrooms on a daily basis and not just in the office.  Overall we're had a great experience!

name: Marie K Jennison School of Dance

review.author: Alex G.
review.description: I went to MKJ for many years and once you hit the young teen years girls start doing company. Now my parents never let me try out for the company team which was upsetting because I was missing out but the worst part was that unless you're in company there wasn't much of an effort to get you involved in the studio or to strengthen your skills. The other girls also made no effort to get close with you unless you're in company and I always felt left out. At my last show I saw a mom come in with gifts for seniors I was the only senior who didn't receive one. \nThey start preparing you well when you're young but once you hit a certain age it can go downhill if you're not in company.

review.author: Ron A.
review.description: My daughter enjoys going there for daycare everyday.  Reasonably priced and the teachers communicate very well.

review.author: melissa c.
review.description:
It really annoys me when a reviewer says that they don't recommend an establishment, but gives no reason for their opinion.

Anyway, I have been very happy with my experience at BKCCC.  My oldest son has been going there for some time now, and my youngest will be enrolling soon.  I am pleased with the activities and the care that they provide.  As a former day care worker, I see more positive in this center than most others I have visited.  No center is perfect because we all parent differently.  I can imagine that the previous poster was upset by the fact that her child was meant to abide by rules - rules that are set forth so that a large group of children can get along and work together.

Everyone that I have met has been kind, caring, and helpful.  Not every personality works with every child, and not every child works well with every program.  If your child is "tough", you may be asked to seek alternative care.  

BTW - not to take shots, but I would not really believe the opinion of a person who rated the RI DMV as five-stars.  Have you ever been there?

review.author: Samantha A.
review.description: I attended BKCCC in the 90s and returned to do my high school senior internship there in 2009. This school is beyond wonderful from both the perspective of a student and and educator. When I have children I would absolutely use this great school for my own kids.

review.author: Nicole D.
review.description: By far the best! My daughter was the kind of kid that stays in the back and never said a word. The days she feels like being that kid is ok with the teachers. Other days they push her to be the energetic/smart little girl she can be at this age. I've seen her vocabulary, sign language, social skills, fine motor skills, and much more surpass most kids her age.  Every morning at drop off she runs to the director to give her a hug. And again in the afternoon at pickup. I've surprised the facility and picked up during nap time to find the director in the toddler room rubbing backs to help them fall asleep. These girls go above and beyond because they love what they do. Taking care of this many little ones can't be easy and yet they light up when they see the kids in the morning. I feel so grateful to have found this place and to know my kids are in good hands while I'm at work is well with the price.

review.author: Shana S.
review.description: They should not be running a daycare. They completely lack the passion or the sensitivity required for taking care of innocent kids - granted kids can be tough sometimes but that's exactly why we pay them through our noses so they can employ efficient and loving caretakers to be with our precious kids while we are working so hard at our jobs! I DO NOT recommend them for kid of any age.

review.author: Lindsay W.
review.description: So happy we transitioned our little ones to Breezy. They've grown so much in a short time and are happy to go to school every day. Lots of outdoor play, sensory exploration, dramatic play and love.

review.author: Jenny P.
review.description: Dr Daycare Smithfield location is absolutely amazing. Sending my son to daycare was extremely hard for me (as it is for any parent). I was nervous and worried to send him, but the team at Dr Daycare Smithfield was understanding, sensitive, and handled all my questions (I had tons!). My son started at 1 year old and my Step Daughter also went through the entire daycare.  Now she is in Kindergarten and is learning to read and write at a fast pace. Not only does the daycare keep your kids safe and healthy with lots of exercise and playing - they also prepare them for school. My son comes home saying a new word everyday, and loves doing art projects. They even taught him how to blow his nose. His teachers Miss Jessica and Miss Kandace are incredible, and I consider them part of our family now. They have a special bond with my son and really care for him.  If you are skeptical and nervous to send your child to daycare. I hear you and I was you, but now I love this daycare and it is such a huge part of our lives. Also they follow all COVID guidelines as directed by the DOH and CDC. Always wearing masks and keeping everything disinfected and clean. I have had no concerns with their compliance. We all just want our kids to be safe!

review.author: Anon U.
review.description:
ATTENTION: DO NOT LEAVE YOUR CHILD AT THE DR DAY CARE SMITHFIELD LOCATION. This location should not even be considered for child care. How they are still open and "caring" for children is beyond me, and it makes me SICK to my stomach for anybody who leaves their child here every single day. From first hand personal experience, your children are NOT SAFE here! They are not being nurtured AT ALL and they're definitely not being loved and cared for the way you would expect your child to be loved and cared for. Especially for the amount of money you are being charged for child care. 
The director and assistant are compulsive, pathological liars. Do not trust them. They will lie to your face about the safety and well being of your children. They lie to dcyf workers investigating complaints made by somebody other than the director herself (so a complaint made by an employee or family member). The male employee is put so high on a pedestal at the Smithfield location that he gets away with abusing children and it's considered "okay" by most employees because they are friends who go out drinking together, even with their administrators.
The employees are "supposedly" mandatory reporters but they are told that they are better off reporting neglect and/or abuse right to the directors rather than to call DCYF on their own (yes, the director Danielle scares her employees into NOT making the call to dcyf) but when the reports are made right to her or her assistant, the allegations are ignored, not taken seriously, or not believed, and of course, swept under the rug.
INFANTS (6 weeks to 1 year) are grabbed by their LIMBS!!!! If they stand in their cribs, the nurturing care takers will grab your babies by the arms, slam them onto their stomachs and yell at them "ENOUGH! GO TO SLEEP!" Once a baby starts being able to wiggle and move around, they're able to bang on the sides of the cribs; the caring and nurturing teacher will grab them by a foot and yank them fast and hard away from the crib side. If a baby is having a hard time falling asleep, or if they typically cry at nap time, they will be forcefully rolled onto their belly and have their backs "patted" aka SMACKED SO HARD its surprising theres never any bruising. If the back smacking doesnt work, theyll literally be left in their crib screaming their head off for the entire two hours (usually more because theyll be the last to get taken out of their crib. Every other child will be removed one at a time and have their diaper changed first). According to the American Academy of Pediatrics (and probably dcyf regulations considering it's a daycare) babies aren't allowed to sleep on their stomachs unless they can roll to that position by themselves but at the Smithfield location, any baby having a hard time settling down is tossed onto their stomachs in hopes that they'll fall asleep quickly so the teacher can go stuff her face with food or wander the hallways or go interrupt other classrooms or go use her cell phone in a bathroom, all while leaving her own classrooms out of ratios for the entire two hour nap time (and theres more than one two hour nap each day)
Parents are made to believe (by the directors) that  their kids are safe because of the multiple cameras placed in every classroom, yet administration does absolutely nothing about the wrongful things that are clearly taking place in all of these classrooms. 
Children at this location, if they soil their diaper in between one of the four regularly scheduled diaper changes, they will not be changed until one of those scheduled times. 
I could go on and on for hours detailing the many reasons a parent should NOT send their child here, or why parents who currently have children here should REMOVE their child from this disgusting place.
And if we're being honest, that infant room is the very first classroom in the building. There's still a long hallway with many more classrooms and horror stories to mention. 
TRUST MY WORD: As a parent, if something, ANYTHING, does not feel right, I promise you from the bottom of my heart IT IS NOT RIGHT!

review.author: Kelly W.
review.description: This daycare is the best I have experienced! The teachers have been so NURTURING from the day my little prince started at 6 weeks! I know every single teacher that care for my son personally. They keep me updated on every little thing that happens in my sons day. The admin team up front are so protective over the children and would do anything to ensure your child is safe! At any point I have a concern it's address immediately and it never happens again. I love this daycare and the teachers!

review.author: Bob B.
review.description: Amazing university. Pictures say 10k words. \n\nFaculty, coaches, parent and facilities are best of the best.

review.author: Rose M.
review.description: Visited with my daughter and was very impressed with their curriculum. The tour was very informative, the guide was fun. Dorms very clean and organized, all buildings look new; innovative businesses center. They have a job service center on campus that places students with jobs. I was impressed with the layout and organization. Activities seem to be frequent to keep students busy (and out of trouble ). They have a bulldog as a mascot who walks the grounds with his caretaker. Very cute seeing the students fawn over him and take selfies. I must end on how incredibly clean and beautiful this campus is.

review.author: Mark K.
review.description: Visited with my daughter and was very impressed with the beauty and maintenance of the buildings. The brick walkways and the architecture was outstanding. The only thing I would do is give the dorms names of great alumni instead of 1-12.

review.author: Neil A.
review.description: I so here every year for a Gordon conference.  Great location for this....  Funny thing about the bookstore at Bryant.  No problem if you need a pack of condoms but if you need some sun screen you are out of luck....

review.author: Paul G.
review.description: Unbelievable campus, professional staff, always clean environment.  Attended a Smithfield Rotary Club event in the Bryant Center.  The Smithfield Rotary holds weekly breakfast meetings here and is always accepting visitors and new members.

review.author: Lucy D.
review.description: Quality educational institution with incredible facilities. The campus is absolutely beautiful.

review.author: Kathy C.
review.description: I just transferred out of Bryant.   I found the professors to be arrogant whose sole purpose of being there was to collect a check.  In fact they didn't  teach well at all.  One professor had taken the liberty to brag about himself by passing out his resume (which listed his GPA as a former student of Bryant) along with the syllabus.  He made a better student than teacher.  ACE is horrible and they are more concerned with talking to thier friends than tutoring.  Academic advisors to be very lazy to the core and the one I had always sounded like I woke her up from a sound sleep.  To top it off education was very poor.  In fact I often heard "I didn't learn anything in this class" from others in the class.  Let's not forget the price.  Very high to put up with this.  I, too, included Bryant on my resume while attending.  While I had sent a few out, no one had ever called.  Don't let Bryant fool you.  They are not as good as they say.  In fact I feel they rip students off.

review.author: Mary G.
review.description: This school use very good hair products !!!\nI absolutely love this school. The students are very knowledgeable and willing to go a great job. The own was very observant making sure the customers were pleased. This is a great school!

review.author: Cherie L.
review.description: This place was is awesome! Get my hair done, enjoyed the jokes and the chill atmosphere!\nNow this place is called Blytheville School of Cosmetology and it is high in colors! I love it!

name: University of Arkansas At Little Rock

review.author: Kristen H.
review.description: These are real emergency responders doing the classes.  They give great practical experience lessons, along with the cheesy Red Cross training videos.  Class wasn't boring in the least bit, he kept my attention the whole time.  They answer emails within hours & are very thorough with what you need to do to prepare for the class.  I highly recommend them.  Their website has a very detailed calender of when classes are held.  I will be using them for my renewals as long as they keep holding classes!

review.author: Janet W.
review.description: Loved it lots of will remember the Sun scene next time but it was a lot of fun lots of life guards so you know your kids are safe while swimming

review.author: Janina M.
review.description:
Nice new facility that opened up earlier this year, I believe just in time for the weather to warm up. Prices are extreme for under 42", at $7 and above 42" is $8. WTH? Only $1 for kids?  Would be better if there was another tier or a bigger gap between the two prices. Infants to 1yo are free. They offer military discount, so be sure to show your ID when you pay ($1 off admission).

There is a kiddie area, red slide that is todder friendly, diving board and two bigger slides (must be over 42"), and a lazy river. 

Plenty of seating around the pools.

Break times are listed so you know when they will be telling everyone to get out for a rest break.

Snack bar prices are a bit high, but straight forward, highest is $4, cheapest is $1. They have an off brand Dippin Dots, Icee, nachos, hot dog, chips, etc.

review.author: Jayda K.
review.description: Over priced and filthy. management was rude. Pool was dirty there are other places to spend money for swimming

name: Cabot Foundation for Arts and Culture

review.author: Rick B.
review.description:
Convenient, capable, and friendly - this low-key gunsmith is a retired Army SGM; hats off to him for his service!  I was very happy to find him so nearby.  

Ken is helping me with my AR10, but I'll also use him for inexpensive FFL transfers in the future.  I enjoyed visiting with him, and my wife loved his cute little dog!!

Highly recommended.

review.author: Michael F.
review.description: Child been going here for a couple years now. Not sure about the judgmental part mentioned in the first two posts. All I know is they teach tumbling and floor exercises well. They teach her confidence and never put her down but they do push her to improve without being overbearing. I recommend this place. I have other daughters and never had any in gymnastics or cheerleading so I am not a professional here all I can say is I live in Benton and I have lived in other areas of Arkansas and enjoy this place. I don't live in Tx and Illinois so I can say my child actually goes here and likes it.

review.author: Amy S.
review.description: Not a clean environment for the children, there are mice in the building. The owner Vicki knows this, and still has not reported the issue. I know this firsthand, also the "teachers" love to take a nap with the children. I'm sorry, but when is it ever ok to nap when the kids are? Who is responsible when they get up and there is not an adult to watch them? I would not recommend the school to anyone.

review.author: Dustin L.
review.description: I normally don't leave reviews unless it's something exceptional. In this case, it is exceptionally bad. This is the third college I've been to and by far the worst. The biggest reason I am leaving such an awful review is the fact that the financial aid office has refused to process my fafsa unless my parents commit tax fraud. They were separate at the time but the school wants them to refile as married not separate. I also owe the school a bit of money since scholarships didn't cover enough and fafsa wasn't processed so I had to solely rely on that. So I got a loan but I was told it wouldn't be active until the first day of classes. That means yet again my attempt to relieve the hold and register for classes was a bust. Next up is the food, the cafeteria seems to constantly under cook food. More specifically the chicken is almost always raw. And third is the teachers, but most specifically an english teacher named Mrs. Carter. Who gave me numerous zeros for assignments I turned in without any explanation why causing me to go from a B to an F in the last few weeks of classes. All in all I do not recommend attending this university.

review.author: Nikki T.
review.description: Nice building, nice people.  Both my sons attend AHS.  The Teachers are responsive and helpful.  The JROTC program is amazing, very active in the community.

review.author: Gino Y.
review.description: Best school ever $$$$$ \nR.I.P Bill Dixon   we all remember you and your lovely wife Snookie Dixon best peoples ever

review.author: Chris C.
review.description: The best college that I have ever attended!!! I would totally recommend Ouachita to anyone that needs to be smarter, but if you want to be smarter be sure that you have enough money to be smart

review.author: Miami S.
review.description: When we heard Sarah Huckabee gradutated from OBU we became very interested. Always curious to ascertain calibre of graduates, learned a lot.

review.author: Susan S.
review.description: Great staff dedicated to district support and student success!

review.author: Samantha N.
review.description: One of the best schools in the area. Consistently high test scores. Smaller class sizes and one on one help. Caring environment. Teachers and staff are great. My parents and I both graduated from Cotter and my kiddo is currently attending.

review.author: Tracy T.
review.description: This place is amazing. Small 'classes' with caretakers that love children and have been there for years. Leaving my daughter here is like leaving her with family. I cloth diapered, sent breast milk, and now organic milk, and homemade baby food for my daughter with no complaints from them. The low turnover rate allows my child to feel comfortable going there and I can work without feeling worried or guilty. Days that I've had to go to work early they adjust their schedule and took her earlier (as early as 5:30 a.m.).\n\nI would change nothing about this childcare center. Someone could offer me free childcare elsewhere and I would not take it. I've tried every daycare in town, licensed in-home providers and babysitters. None compare to Bright Start. There aren't enough stars to rate how I feel about them!

review.author: Stacy D.
review.description: Not very equipped or trained to do African American hair. Even just plain hair braiding and ponytails are messy. Need more culture at this facility.

review.author: K O.
review.description: I am only giving this  4 out of 5 starts right now since my kids have been attending for just a month although I am happy with the place. (I will update my rating after school starts up again.)  So far I like that the kids can come at any time on any or all of the five days that it is open and can get one-on-one help with tutors for the entire 1 hour session if they want it.  I also like that at the end of each session a progress report for each kid is provided to the parent which tells what the kids worked on, what they have accomplished and what they need to work on.  The kids get instant rewards for completing session work to keep them motivated, and also earn "cards" they can save up and exchange for prizes in the future.\n\nThe facility is always clean and orderly, and the people who work there are friendly and helpful.  If you have more than one kid enrolled at a time there is a discount on the others.  The owner is very nice and works with the kids as well.

review.author: Linda C.
review.description: Mathnasium's individualized curriculum based on my children's assessment has help them set the foundation for strong math skills. We attend the math center 4 days a week and I think the consistency is also key to their success. My 8th and 5th grader really enjoy going to Mathnasium. My 8th grader in Algebra 1 says "tutors are great with helping her prepare for upcoming tests". My 5th grader improved his Maps math score by 10 points. Mathnasium is not just for those struggling in math but keeps them on track to success.

review.author: David S.
review.description: Ugh...that first review on the haunted house was horrendous. It was so painful to read. The grammar and spelling made it feel like my brain was walking across a field of sharpened Lego pieces. I mean, there's a spell checker on Yelp and most computers/phones that you would write a review on have spelling and grammar checks that would literally take less than a minute to complete. Anyway, the college here is best described as cows grazing in a field. They're eating and moving around but not really doing anything or going anywhere. There's a few professors here who are diamonds in the rough but most should have spent their education careers at a daycare thanks to their insatiable egos and apathy. I went here for my basics to stay close to friends and family but eventually got tired of the lazy administrative staff that could care less about whether you enroll or get benefits and moved on to a standard four-year for my BA. I actually had to pay for one of my semesters out of pocket because they incorrectly submitted my VA benefits in spite of me working with them. After speaking to several classmates over the year and change I was there, I came to realize that my experience was a pretty regular occurrence with many, not just vets. Never in my entire life have I seen employees who care so little about their job or their clients and will do anything to get out of doing work. Sure, you're greeted with a smile, a handshake, and some wonderful sounding promises, but behind all that shallow fluff, you're being dismissed in the minds of the faculty and staff.

review.author: amy t.
review.description: HAUNTED HOUSE  This is not for the college per say..My husband me and my children went here last night for their Kids Bash.. Although I know several of the people that attend this university, You were unable to see their faces because it was so dark, they had masks on and were painted up. We had to take a hayride into the "woods" (the haunted house was on campus) Then you had to get off and walk across the broken down bridge. Finally you get to the house, its all black and all you can see is flashing lights. Our tour guide told us to stay close and dont get lost. When we first walked in it was a guy just lying on a couch with a knife in hes chest. Pretty funny if you ask me, he was trying to be slick and scare everyone by waking up. You couldnt see where the hell you were going so I have no idea who or what was in front of me and suddenly SMACK a freaking doll hit me on the head. They had dolls hanging by there necks suspended from the ceiling. The next room that was lit up was of a women vampire, she didnt do anything but smile, so she sucked!! We went on this damn bus, I didnt even know we were on a bus till our tour guide yelled "watch your step were getting off the bus now". What I was freakin out when the hell did I get on this bus???Next we went across another bridge and of course people were grabbing your legs, which was pretty funny because im so ticklish. But we get off the bridge and were in what looks to be a Forest, trees everywhere I lost my husband somewhere in the damn forest so im freaking out, IM LOST!! Suddenly all you could hear is roaring chainsaws all around me and Star,(my oldest daughter) as she had stayed with me.  They started chasing us, my daughter started screaming so I had to hold her all 40 pounds of her and make my way through this forest. Whomever it was they thought it was pretty funny and started poking me and her with the damn prop. Im not going to lie I was scared shit less. I should have gotten high before going in there!! Finally after running to catch up with my husband I fucking pushed him so hard into the damn wall, now that was funny!!!! I couldnt tell you what was after the forest because I just closed my eyes and hoped it would be coming to the end very soon. We finally got out of the house, and making our way back to the old ass bridge to cross that and go back on the hay ride one of the guys with the chainsaw started chasing me and Star again. He/She didnt go after my husband nor the others. My husband was rolling with laughter. So im wondering if it was someone we knew. He wont tell me. But it was pretty fun.. Worth the trip down there to see!

review.author: Carolyn E.
review.description: I could not be happier than I am with this school.  Both my children have attended since its beginning, then we moved and they attended an excellent public school for one year in Virginia. When we found out we could move back to the area if we wanted (while the husband went over seas) there was no hesitation to do so.  A HUGE reason we made this decision was because of Little Scholars.  They are very caring and professional.  The class sizes are not found in any other school in the area and each child gets personal instruction designed for their learning needs/level.  I have asked both my children which school setting they liked better and they both agreed they preferred little scholars but didn't dislike public schools. (Being perfectly honest) as a parent I know without a doubt they are getting a far superior education than they would be getting at any public school.   This school does mix in traditional school with Montessori and I love that fact.  Most will move from the Montessori setting on to a more traditional setting (like we did for one year) and these children will have little if any issues transitioning.  Neither of my children had any problems adjusting to the public school routine and then adjusting back to Montessori.  \n\nI am a very happy parent and would recommend Little Scholars to anyone with an interest in developing foundations for future learning to check them out.

review.author: Natalie S.
review.description: I enrolled both my children at Little Scholars Montessori ! When I first went to observe this school I knew that I had found the place I wanted my children to begin their education experience ! My children learned so much and really enjoyed being there on a daily basis. They gained confidence in their social interactions and in their abilities to read and write. They learned about different cultures and customs and became aware of our world. I am so happy that they received such a strong base to begin their education! I highly recommend this school! The staff is AMAZING! Just STUNNING! We love them. They have helped me so much with my children. My village is complete because of them!

review.author: Dee B.
review.description: Office staff is rude and hateful. No manners, and this is majority of the time. Toxic environment.

review.author: Caroline B.
review.description: Both my 6 and 4 year old attend here! We love the staff and all the office peeps! Great great place!!! I wouldn't trust my children anywhere else!

name: Bethel University College of Professional Studies

review.author: Alexander P.
review.description: This school is the best it has such great teachers and I am absolutely amazed by this school

review.author: Dread M.
review.description: I went to the middle school and it sucks, from teachers, student behavio, food, bathrooms. The teachers are "Ok" as most are only there to get money and leave and don't care, but there is a few that stand out, such as the librarians or the extra curricular teachers. Ive caught students having sex in the bathrooms with weed, vapes, cigarettes. The food is absolutely horrible as is they serve nacho cheese the cheese is a solid, and the bread is hard as a brick, the pizza horrible and its sauce is brown and not even close to red

review.author: Samirah S.
review.description: The middle school sucks. my daughter goes to this school and she has gotten jumped many times because she said that someone was death and mrs. Batts don't get me started she is extremely racist she told my daughter who is black that her race was the reason for the world's problems. Not only that but my daughter said she had gotten iss for going outside and she got iss because there was a code medical

review.author: Brylee C.
review.description:
I would attend just about any school before going here, and here's why: 

If you're considering going to Miller-Motte in order to make a better future for yourself, please do as much research as possible. Not all schools are created equally nor are the instructors who ultimately hold huge sway in the likelihood of your success. A lot of reviewers take time to discuss accreditation. This review is not going to be one of them, but that's an important topic as well considering that many reviewers attempted to transfer credit earned at MMTC to another school and were unable to do so. Please check into where you can take your credits, especially if you are Military personnel or a dependent and are going to relocate prior to your graduation. 

I attended their massage therapy school and initially felt good about that decision. 
The people who were responsible for enrolling me were kind and helpful and seemed to be genuinely interested in the success of their students. It wasn't until I was well into the program that I began to second guess everything. 

First off, the scheduling for the LMT students is extremely inflexible. If you have a full time job and are the primary breadwinner of your household, you're gonna have a bad time (quoting the South Park meme, here). The reason for this is is because the classes run from about 8 in the morning until between 2 p.m. and 7:30 at night. You will be going at a minimum of 6 hours/day 5 days/week and depending on the class will be given ample amounts of homework, making this essentially a full time job. This is doable if you have a lot of grant/loan money to make up the difference for missed work while you're in the program or have a spouse who can support you while you're completing the program, but if you are already working a 50 hour a week job, have nobody to help you and are a single parent doing all of this, you will struggle. 

I won't mention names, but I met at least a couple of women who were working minimum wage jobs full time as single parents who had to drop out, were sleeping in class because of the grueling schedules they kept and who not only had no support from the faculty, but who were bad-mouthed in class by their instructors to other students. I witnessed this firsthand; the instructors were ridiculing these students during class and were marking down their grades with little to no explanation. 

Two instructors who work at the Clarksville, TN campus, one of which still works there, were particularly problematic. It didn't matter how much you applied yourself, how dedicated you were as a student: if they didn't like you as a person, you would get D's and C's. You would get disciplined for anything and everything while other students whom they liked slept during class, came in late, and acted generally disrespectful. I realize that some students don't take their education seriously and deserve the low GPA, but I'm not talking about these people. There is a genuine lack of professionalism with Miller-Motte's faculty and I would go so far as to call some of the instructors bullies. 

For example: one woman in our Swedish Massage class was called out for needing to use the bathroom "too often"; the same instructor made sarcastic, snide comments in front of us over anything and everything she did. If she did what every other student does and had a snack in class, she was called out for it. If she was late like every other student was from time to time, she suffered more serious consequences. When the director was informed, she tried to help, but it was impossible to convey the seriousness of what was happening when it was so hard to prove. But we saw what was going on; we just kept our heads down and said nothing because we were afraid of our GPAs being affected. 

Another instructor made a huge scene over a student over god knows what; she said she "felt disrespected" by them, but they were being quiet in class, doing their work, and didn't say much. Apparently, it was the fact that she "wasn't providing enough feedback in class" that irked the instructor, so for the remainder of the year, she was targeted for arbitrary and completely irrelevant reasons. 
This, again, while the more favored students could be late, loud and inconsiderate, have their late attendance overlooked and so on. 

I tried to take my complaints to Academic Affairs after the stress of being in such an unhealthy, unprofessional environment began to take its toll on my ability to even focus in class, but was dismissed largely because I wasn't directly involved. Now that I'm licensed and out of there, however, I feel like I have an obligation to speak out so that others who spend thousands of dollars and invest so much time, energy and effort to try and build a better future for themselves aren't jeopardized. Avoid this school if you can.

review.author: Mandy T.
review.description: I am a photographer and I have photographed the work of the Cosmo and esthetics students. This spa/salon is a school so it's not the typical salon environment that you are used to but don't let that fool you! You will get great service at really low prices. The students and instructors are very talented and dedicated to their work!

name: Center for Aquatic Sciences at Adventure Aquarium

review.author: Bjorn H.
review.description: My girlfriend, daughter, and two friends went to Pinot's Palette Cherry Hill location on December 26, 2021. The artist did a great job directing us and the staff was friendly and supportive.  We all had a great time and will do this again!  Highly recommend

review.author: Brian S.
review.description: first off I'm very thankful they made it happen I called last minute on the day off & they did everything they could to accommodate us. We had Amazing time! our instructor was very fun lively & interactive. She made my girlfriends  birthday party one she won't forget!  We were walked thru how to do everything, she made time for us to enjoy each other while painting. it was an amazing time. they really worked with us to make it a time we won't forget. She definitely deserves more then what she's paid. They gave her a free painting for her birthday and a birthday card canvas. I love this place!!!

review.author: Carol E.
review.description: I had done the blacklight party and had so much fun doing it. Our instructor was great and our paintings came out awesome!!!! We painted in the blacklight for about 90% of the time and the music playlist was fun n upbeat. The place itself is new and has a great view of the stores in the plaza and even Philly. Pinot's has so many other options that other paint events & places at comparable prices. They even have a truck to take things mobile. If youre looking for a different kind of paint party where you'll be happy with the results and have a fantastic time, then this is the place to go to. Thank you to Rosa & Tre Thomas who have a beautiful establishment and ensured a great time!

review.author: Tabby W.
review.description: My friend and i went last night had a great time... i really enjoyed the instructor, she was fun and willing to help with the little details. I think the fact they have Ice and glasses made a nice touch.  I will definitely go back!

review.author: Kat M.
review.description: Attended recently with a large group of folks attending a wedding shower. Enjoyed it immensely and not just because of the people I was with. The individual who lead us on our way to becoming Van Goghs (apologies for forgetting her name) was really good at facilitating our very large group and keeping us all in sync. Highly recommend this activity/venue for any group looking for something a little different and a lot of fun!

review.author: Dennis S.
review.description: As someone who is not a parent, this is not a place that I would usually seek out. But I was lucky to have the opportunity to stumble upon PlayArts for my friends' daughter 1st birthday party yesterday. The building of PlayArts is interesting as it used to be a historical public bath but it's converted into a children's activity center. The entrance to PlayArts on Front Street was a bit confusing as I had to go to the back entrance on Lee Street. But the staff didn't really communicate it properly and I had to call my friends who were hosting the event for directions to the birthday party entrance. The back entrance for the event has multiple shoe cubbies where you can put your shoes in. Then I entered a spacious room which was where the birthday party was in with a very long picnic table and birthday decor. What was very notable for me was seeing staff interactions with the children and how kind, genuine, and engaged they were with the child attendees in the birthday party. PlayArts seems like a great spacious place to customize into any theme and definitely is a great place to host events for children! Thanks PlayArts :)

review.author: Selena H.
review.description:
What an amazing space!  I've been wanting to attend a drop in play session for a while, but when PlayArts held a special mini photo session in collaboration with a local photographer, and free play after the photos, I jumped on the deal!

While not part of the normal business operations, the mini photo session was amazing - in a private room in the back, plenty of time for my daughter to feel comfortable and get a number of amazing photos. 

Then we moved to the play space and let my toddler go wild! The space is truly safe and entertaining for crawling babies through older elementary aged kids, with areas only the older kids could access and plenty to keep the younger kids entertained. We spent a solid hour, my child had a ball, and she was exhausted and took a loooong nap afterwards. 

I'm so happy we have a space like this in Fishtown, and we look forward to more playtime!

They also are available to hold private parties, and it's definitely a space I'll consider as my child gets older and we have parties with other kids attending.

review.author: R. S.
review.description: This place is everything! Hosted a 6-year-old birthday party at the peak of omicron and it worked -- the space is large with good air filters and circulation so people felt comfortable coming. We had about a dozen, masked the whole time, and the kids ran around like crazy having the times of their lives.  We were afraid a party wouldn't be possible...PlayArts to the rescue!

review.author: Dominique R.
review.description: It's a cool building but there's no toys in there ... it's pretty boring use of space with not much to do.

review.author: Morris B.
review.description:
I heard about this place thru an old coworker and decided at was a great saturday to try it out with the baby. Parking was pretty easy. As soon as we walked in I couldn't help but notice how vibrant but not too overwhelmingly bright it was. The decor was modern and well thought out as far as spacing. 

There was plenty for kids to do and they even have a big beautiful birthday room. And lots of comfy seating for tired parents lol.
 The hours and price point are great too and THEY DON'T CHARGE PARENTS AN ENTRY FEE like some other places. (it's only 12 bucks for drop-in and your first time is free if you give 24-hour notice online.) 

I will definitely be bringing our child back here. They even have fitness and social groups for parents btw!

review.author: Laura A.
review.description:
Argh!! Yelp glitch deleted my review! In sum: gorgeous space, sustainable toys for collaborative and imaginary play, and an affordable drop in price. I can come with my son and do work or read in the upstairs section while keeping an eye on him while sipping my coffee- living the dream, am i right?

The nest needs to up their game majorly to compete with this place. 

Pro tip.. if you have an older kid like mine (he's 4), arrive around 11:30 on the weekends. The younger kids and nappers clear out then! Also, your first visit is free!

review.author: Catherine L.
review.description:
Super adorable little kid play mecca in you-blinked-and-Fishtown-changed-overnight.

The building is really cool, a former bath house (no, not that kind of bath house), and it has really cool bones (see what I did there?). With exposed brick and some new skylights, the inside is airy and bathed in light even on a rainy day. The interior is well conceived and has a very modern Scandinavian industrial esthetic with a couple thin bright neon metal trees perched in the main play space.

There are at least a dozen separate play spaces with duplos, train tracks, dress up, magna-tiles, fuzzy green 'grass' reading nook, little trikes, play kitchen, climbing castle and a two floor play house, along with a little crawling hideaway. The toys on the whole, seemed to be sourced part Etsy, part Ikea, part Melissa and Doug, along with tons of European imports like HAPE and Plan toys.

There's a classroom in the back for classes, parties and a variety of specific kiddo activities. There are entrances both at the front and back of the building and there is an observation elevated space dedicated for snacking, for working and most importantly, for coffee drinking. The snack/coffee area is on an honor system (which I love - yes, we are adults!), offers a variety of kid friendly snacks (not just junk, unless you consider pirate booty, junk? ha!) beverages, along with Perrier and coffee (did I mention, there was coffee?)  Yes, there is coffee. Thank god.

Unsurprisingly, the place is packed on weekends and especially on rainy days. As far as the age group it appeals to, my preschooler finds it lots of fun, although the majority of the population that I have observed in there is younger.  When the space is in fully over-run, staff could make efforts to better organize the space, and there should be perhaps labels as to what's where, or where things should go? (would that ruin the whole look?) The house and castle have some perilous stairs/ladders that require more parents oversight (helicoptering?) than I would like and I wish there was a tumbling section or a little climbing wall so we could really tire the kiddos out. Without a membership, you are out $12 per walk-in visit per kid. Much better play space than the underground Nest downtown.

review.author: Jonny R.
review.description: Loved the space, and so did the kids, ages two and five (but the whole party ranged from two to ten). We were there for a birthday party and the two hours flew by. The music circle with the big drum was great, and so is the play area. We aren't members, so I can't endorse a membership, necessarily, but we did think it was great for a party and we'll consider booking it in the future.

review.author: nic j.
review.description: Great toys and great space to the kids to play. \nWe have been to a lot of different play areas but playarts is by far the best I have seen. Usually this places are a madhouse but here is it a much more calm environment even when there is a lot of people around. Fosters community not chaos. \nGear music also.

review.author: Joe B.
review.description:
We do the playground circuit in Fishtown pretty often - Shissler, Fishtown Rec., Liberty Lands in Northern Liberties, Cione Playground, etc. On a colder day this past February, we decided we still need to get out and moving, so we visited PlayArts, and it was well worth the visit!

The old cliche about first impressions is true. And PlayArts nails it. From the moment you walk in, you're greeted in a nice, clean reception area by PlayArts personnel who explain to you the concept, the rules of play, and the pricing scale. We initially decided to visit just for the day, but midway through our visit, I decided to go with a monthly plan. The kids had that much fun.

Highlights include: tons of interactive toys, play areas for older toddlers as well as kids as young as a few months old, cool seating areas for parents, the snack/coffee/tea mezzanine area, the cash-free policy, etc.

This past summer, we held our son's birthday party here as well. And it was awesome. Both the kids and parents had a great time. I could base my 5-star review entirely on the party because it was that excellent of an experience: from booking, to communication with PA staff, to the execution the day-of. I have a feeling it won't be our last party there!

review.author: Laura M.
review.description: This is not a great playspace for anyone under the age of 3. There are a lot of climbing playspaces, and a lot of small toys for older toddlers and children. It is also a very loud space, and very expensive compared to other playspaces in the city.

review.author: P. D.
review.description: I love the fact that the parents can setup shop upstairs and observe from a birds eye view.  It's bright and beautiful.  But, this place is really better for older children since there are no physical barriers to separate the toys by ages. So with my toddler, there are toys that she can walk to that I consider choking hazards.  They warn you at check-in about this, but I still think that's something they could work on.

review.author: A A.
review.description: PlayArts changed my life! It's the absolute best addition to the neighborhood - super friendly staff, beautifully designed space, and most of all kiddos love it. If you're raising a kid in the city, you NEED to become a member, especially in the winter months.

review.author: Shani F.
review.description: PlayArts is a magical new addition to Philadelphia's array of offerings for children.  The teachers are extremely skilled and support the interests and abilities of kids of all ages and abilities.

review.author: Jessica O.
review.description: Let's just start by saying my 2 year old LOVES this place! We live in MT Airy/Germantown section of philly so it is a bit far for us, but well worth the trip! After coming here a few times I decided that we had to become members! I'm so glad I did. The first fridays are awesome and it's BYOB so you get to have a few drinks while watching your little run wild lol! Very clean, welcoming and relaxed environment. The staff are always friendly and welcoming to my family. Usually when we go we're there all day and when it's time to leave my son has a fit! So glad I found this place. No charge for parents which I think is awesome! And for former Chesnut hill Nest members (they recently closed down and I thought my world would end) this place is awesome. With winter quickly approaching and having a very rambunctious 2 year old little man this will be our new home and I am very happy about that! Thank you Play Arts! You da bomb!!

review.author: David S.
review.description: I had my daughter's 1st birthday party at PlayArts. We had about 60 people including kids and it was amazing. Everyone had a blast. Obviously the space is fantastic but the team was equally as wonderful.

review.author: J M.
review.description: PlayArts is amazing! My 2.5 year old loved the music class and it was very age appropriate. I also loved the parent engagement as well. The teachers were enthusiastic and the flow of the class felt perfect. I can't wait to take more classes!!

review.author: Tara J.
review.description: The play space is modern, very clean, and fun. We had a 1st birthday party here and everything was perfect from start to finish. They provided the decor, cups, plates, water, etc. It was nice not having to worry about all that. You can bring your own food and drinks and they will set it up/clean it up. Party room is huge. Staff is very nice and helpful. Memberships, daily rates, and party fees are all very reasonable. Can't say enough great things about this place!

review.author: Juliet A.
review.description: This review is about hosting a birthday party there. The good: play space is spacious and fun with good music; can do a private rental. The bad: for all the money we paid we expected a stress free party. Unfortunately, the two "helpers" that were there were not well trained. They were polite but did not know where to place food or how to host. Most of the food and drinks stayed downstairs even though most of the parents were upstairs. They kept asking me what to do even though i was busy trying to keep up with the birthday toddler while trying to speak with some of the guests at least. This included very common sense things like should we serve cake before or after pizza. They  spent most of their time talking to each other in the back instead of ensuring the party was running smoothly. The birthday girl did not have a central seat at the table and ended up with trash in the back ground of her photos. And the list goes on. So while the space is cool,hosting a party there is stressful as you provide all the food and do the hosting and only get very basic decorations (no themes) plus plates/cups with little help and no guidance. They even charge for ice despite the hundreds you'll spend. Hopefully they'll come up with better packages and trained staff in the future.

review.author: Weena D.
review.description:
I enrolled in the EMT-B program during the Feb2016-Jun2016 term and had an absolutely phenomenal experience. Jamie and Bubba, the two main instructors, not only ensured my class and I completed the program with the necessary skills to be a competent EMT, but they personally mentored and instilled confidence in each and every single one of us. Before I knew it, I began to see my instructors and classmates as my second family as well.

The curriculum follows the NREMT guidelines and is broken into in-class lectures, online assignments, and psychomotor skill practical days (once a month on Sundays). The course is definitely challenging and will require work on your part. If you do not put the necessary time and energy into practicing and studying, it will show through. However, the support Jamie and Bubba provides will ensure you do not risk falling behind. 

What I believe sets Drexel's EMT program apart from all others is simply the passion and dedication Jamie and Bubba possess for educating the next generation of emergency medical providers. They take immense pride in teaching their students and watching them succeed in becoming certified EMT-B. They are truly two of the most, if the not the most, committed educators I have had the pleasure to learn from. It was an honor and pleasure to have learned from them.

If anyone has any questions on the program or wish to learn more, I would be more than happy to speak with you and provide more in-depth details of my time there.

P.S. I received my EMT-B certification within less than a month of completing the course.

review.author: Ellie R.
review.description:
I took the EMT-B program with the Department of Emergency Medicine and could not possibly have had a better experience. I left not only with the skills needed to obtain my certification, but with the support of a fantastic group of EMS professionals who became like a second family to me over the duration of the course.

The course follows the NREMT training guidelines and was kept stringently up-to-date with new protocols, so rest assured that you will leave with the skills to handle any emergency situation you may find yourself in. The training is split between in-person lectures and online skill reviews, with a couple of in-depth skill drilling days as the exam (!!) draws nearer.

That said, this is the basic format that I would expect from any high-quality EMT-B course. What makes the Drexel program stand head and shoulders above the rest is the people who teach it. My course was taught by Jamie Teufel, who to this day remains one of my favorite instructors I have ever had, in any discipline. His genuine passion for EMS combined with his unwavering dedication to the success of his students made the class not just a requirement, but an absolute pleasure to take. Personally invested in each member of the class, he guided us through the convoluted process (get it together, NREMT and PADOH -- you're killing a small forest with the number of forms we have to fill out) with a seemingly endless supply of patience and knowledge.

I could not more highly recommend that anyone interested in becoming a certified EMT take their course through the Drexel University College of Medicine -- as long as Jamie is there, and you're willing to do the legwork, I guarantee it will be one of the best experiences of your life. If you have any questions about my experience taking the course, please don't hesitate to reach out -- I would love to expand on many of the details I couldn't include here in the name of brevity.

review.author: Q P.
review.description:
The EMT-B program at Drexel is second to none. I came in with uncertainty in my ability and left with so much knowledge and confidence in my ability to treat patients. 

Jamie Teufel, the course director and one of the instructors, is extremely passionate about teaching. Although I had never planned in practicing as an EMT because I was planning to pursue an M.D., I learned so much that has actually benefited me now that I am in medical school.

Some background, I am the quintessential socially awkward nerd who is afraid to touch a patient but can tell you a lot about Biochemical pathways. As a result, I was quite terrified about not being good enough in terms of communication and being a physician who is more than a nerd. If you work in the medical field, you know that effective communication, with patients and fellow health-care providers, is imperative to good care. But rest assured, I was not to be left hanging. 

Jamie and Bubba, our main instructors, made sure that all of us not only learned how to be basic EMTs but how to be competent providers. While there is a lot of work to be done, it is designed to give us the most for our time and accelerate us to be our best. The curriculum consists of both lectures and labs that are designed to teach us the roles of an EMT and the physical and communication skills that are expected of us. There are a variety of labs from a pig lab (in which we explore the lung and heart anatomy of a pig) to a Mass Casualty Incident (MCI) day in which we utilize all our skills in a simulated environment. While time consuming, these labs and labs in which we practice our skills are designed to train us in becoming proficient providers.

In addition to a well-designed and implemented curriculum, Jamie and Bubba are ALWAYS there to address your concerns. Because there are numerous labs, some may have time conflicts, but Jamie is always willing to work with you to ensure that you get the best education that you can. They are highly flexible because their goal is to create the best EMTs/health-care providers, and for good reason- we represent the institution when we practice. There is NO room for sub-par work!

I highly recommend this program for anyone interested in becoming an EMT and anyone who is interested in becoming a health-care provider in general. These skills that are taught are the FOUNDATIONS to becoming competent health-care provider and can easily distinguish the "good" providers from the excellent.

TLDR: Excellent program with phenomenal instructors who have high standards for their students. There's a lot of work but you'll learn a lot and become a better health-care provider because of it. On the fence? Try it out, you won't regret it.

name: Dickinson School of Law Legal Clinics

review.author: Chuck K.
review.description: Maybe I'm biased because I have Columbia University so close by but I didn't find UPenn's campus all that impressive.  Finding parking was difficult and the campus just seemed so old.  I know it's an Ivy League school, but it wasn't that aesthetically pleasing.  Or maybe it's my anti-Philly bias.  I don't know.  I can safely say it's the least attractive campus from the Ivies that I've visited.

review.author: Clare D.
review.description: I attended Penn Engineering for my PhD from 1989 to 1991, then stopped to pursue life's passions, got a job at Penn, got engaged, married, had children, divorced, and still work here. I'm a "lifer." I'm currently going for my third master's degree at the Law School. The campus is a beautiful place. When I first arrived here in 1989, it was kind of seedy outside the campus in West Philly. Not going to lie, I was afraid to stay out past 8pm. Moving to Center City was probably the best idea. The resources of this university are vast, so whatever you want to study, you can probably find it here. I do wish I attended this school as an undergrad because it seems the people who love this school the most are undergrads, but I do not regret the path I took to get here. If I had to do it all over again, I'd probably stay in Boston and go to the big H.

review.author: Tiffany T.
review.description: I was in town for a conference and wanted to check out the famous UPenn campus. The campus is located a few miles outside of downtown Philly. Surrounding the campus are other schools as well. \n\nThe campus was beautiful in the fall. It is situated in the heart of a city, one moment you passing shake shake and minutes away you're on campus. The campus is pretty easy to navigate. A clean environment and very safe. Definitely seems like a great ivy league to attend!

review.author: Aelita P.
review.description:
I went to Penn as an undergraduate and work here currently, BUT I'm going to write this review from the perspective of a visitor. Physically, Penn is a beautiful space. It's been officially recognized as an arboretum for its cultivation of diverse plant species. 

It's not a large campus, but there are a lot of cool nooks to wander in. My favorite space is the "Bio Pond:" great for eating lunch, wandering, and/or watching turtles sunbathe. Locust walk is incredibly beautiful as well. In the summer you're walking under various shades of green and in the winter you can walk under glowing golden lights. 

If you're in the city I think Penn is well worth a walking tour.

review.author: Bella R.
review.description: Long overdue!\nI had the honor of taking a course with Professor  David bell and my experience has been unforgettable since. He's passionate about marketing and takes the time to thoroughly answer everyone's questions. He's patient and makes learning fun! Professor Bell taught one of the students (founder) of WarbyParker glassses and used their experience to teach about online marketing and the new digital world. \nAlso, had the honor to sit down with him for dinner with my GM and made me wish I had gone to apply for Grad school with UPENN!! My General Manager also loved taking his course and we both utilized some of his strategies to propose to our boss which was effective!

review.author: Marina G.
review.description:
Part 1. This was the worst experience with a university in my life. I have two undergraduate depress from exceptional school, one in a consortium with U Penn. Those two previous schools were excellent in the treatment of students, teaching, provided health services, advising, and on and on. U.Penn. fails students, at least graduate nursing students, horribly. Just look at the suicide rate. Also, this past year the new head of the mental health center killed himself after working here just 8 months I believe. He had come from Cornell, a notoriously depressing place. Penn is a dangerous cruel environment that you should avoid if you care about your sanity or education at all. 
I tried to contact my advisor when I started here. She didn't respond for over six months. I finally went to the general student adviser, but sadly she quit. The advisors I had, and there were multiple, were selfish, unhelpful, and generally failing their advisees. Penn does little to help the student or guide them. I had to jump through a large number of hoops for the graduate nursing program and Penn did nothing to make this easier for the students. There was no advisor guidance, paper instructions, nothing to help make it easier. 
We were required to provide health records, but Penn didn't accept mine for some reason even though my prior employer (a hospital) accepted and provided them. They wanted to re-vaccinate me for literally everything. 
Getting licensed in NJ and DE is not easy and Penn doesn't help you. 
They don't bring in someone to do flu shots for the nursing student or give step by step instructions on where to go to fulfill the licensing procedures. I found that the advisor really only cares about doing his or her own research, teaching is a distant second, and helping students comes last if at all. 
When I started there they said they wanted us to succeed and they would do everything they could to help us do that. That's a blatant lie. If you send an e-mail with multiple questions, I know from experience you will either get a response to only one of your questions or get turfed off to someone else to answer you.  If you need extra help in a class and ask the professor where to find someone to tutor you, they either don't know or send you to someone who is tutoring 15 other people at the same time and only shows up about 3 out of 8 sessions because he or she is busy too. 
Yelp is saying my review is too long, so I'll do another review as part two.

review.author: Angie L.
review.description: I had a very dreary forecast of UPenn coming in, but after spending just one minute on campus, I realized I was dearly mistaken. Academics aside, the campus is just gorgeous. Red bricks form the walkways, which are heavily shaded by rows of towering trees. The buildings are historic, but not old or run-down enough to the point of archaism. \n\nI attended an info session and campus tour, which were both fine in their own right (I got a bunch of free "fancy brochures", which I'm definitely not complaining about), but the campus itself made the biggest impression. The off-campus atmosphere was mediocre at best, but the on-campus environment proved itself to be homely and relaxing and just a wonderful place to spend an afternoon (or four years) at. Stop on by, I recommend it.

review.author: Joop V.
review.description:
I had a privilege to study at the University of Pennsylvania for my undergrad and loved it so much that I chose to go back there again for my graduate degree a few years after I finished my undergrad!

Aside from being in an urban area, what I particularly like about Penn are the interdisciplinary approach to teaching and a strong focus on exposure to international/cultural awareness. While I was there, I had a chance to take classes from business and engineering to urban studies and foreign languages (I even got to take American Sign Language class, too!).

My friends all are successful in the paths and passions they choose to pursue. The university does an excellent job providing theoretical knowledge but also equipping its students with practical sense on how to operate and apply what they learn to the real world!

review.author: Nancy H.
review.description:
I'm tempted to write about Penn from an academic and student culture perspective, since everyone here has plenty opinions about that. But since this is Yelp, I'm going to direct my attentions to people who are going to visit this place for the beauty of the campus, or who are thinking of living nearby, and not to try to impose my opinion on prospective students (who should be asking current students 1:1 for college-picking advice anyway). 

Penn's campus's big cohesive force is Locust Walk, which connects the high rise residences (where a lot of students end up living, either in the high-rises or on cheap off-campus housing) all the way to the buildings on the far sides of campus. This brick boulevard is lined with trees and keeps the campus from feeling like just another part of the city. Walking down Locust sort of feels like walking through an actual park, especially at night when the hordes of students have trickled down to just you and your footsteps. 

Penn's buildings are quite grand and beautiful, especially Fisher Fine Arts Library, which is so nice that drawing classes tend to come here to sketch its innards. The New College House, on the other hand, is very contemporary and decked out with cool tech for its residents. Finally, the high-rises offer views that you don't get tired of for your entire undergrad career, and only suck in the winter when they form wind tunnels of hell that blow you backwards while you struggle towards your dorm. 

Foodwise, the campus is ringed with tons of restaurants, but the best food is across the bridge near Rittenhouse Square. Same with groceries -- there are some expensive, meh-quality places to get ingredients on campus, but Trader Joe's has by far the fresher produce and fairer prices. 

Time sort of passes instantaneously while walking around campus after you get used to it, and I've learned to cut through certain buildings to shave off five minutes or so from my commute at a time. As a student the campus feels smaller and smaller every year, but the streets named after tree varieties never quite become engrained into memory, and in freshman year I remember getting lost between 38th and 39th.

review.author: Ivan R.
review.description: A top school in engineering and applied sciences, with top faculty and cutting-edge research.

review.author: Lauren K.
review.description: Forget the tour, Writ 089-302 Policing Social Media is an objectively wild attraction on campus.

review.author: Joyce J.
review.description: I will not rate the school according to its educational excellence. The whole world knows that Penn is one of the best universities.  I am just reviewing it based on my tourist experience ;) \n\nMy husband being an alumnus,  acted as my tour guide. I liked how there are lots of trees and plants around a campus in the middle of a city.  The buildings are beautiful and historic. The lay out of the campus seem convenient and fun for the students.

review.author: Dominik D.
review.description: Fairly beautiful campus. So much history can be absorbed just by walking around. It's spacious despite its urban setting.

review.author: Hank C.
review.description:
I really enjoyed living and going to classes (when I could wake up for them) here.

While there are the downsides (inevitably, cockroaches, dirty roommates in  the dorms, crazy people begging, and what a cost ... my wallet still hurts), there were plenty of plusses.

For the people who complain about Penn contributing nothing... consider that it's one of the largest employers in the region, contributing to countless people's income in that regard. The students and staff use millions of dollars worth of local supplies and spend plenty of money in the city proper, not just on-campus. While students are encouraged to be careful of the surroundings, it's no where near as dangerous to students as more than a dozen years ago.

While some of the buildings were old and scary (ever check out the basement in DRL?), others are brand-spanking new and spit-polished shiny (Huntsman, anyone?), and the University does try hard to make everything close enough for students to access for those who either don't wish to go downtown or don't know better to go downtown.  The food carts were a blessing at almost all hours, the cafeteria food wasn't really that bad (although the service was inconsistent), and Wawa was always open to serve up a sandwich for you. Over the years, more bike lanes appeared and more cops patrol the area, and a facelift was given to Houston Hall / Perelman Quad, the Quad itself got air conditioning, and the high rises were given new names (although I'll still refer to them all as High Rise East, North, and South), and new windows & paint.

1920 Commons still can't match Hill for food, but they added many fast food options on-campus from a Taco Bell to Subway. While I miss my Burger King, the food carts, again, help to make up for it.  Fresh Grocer now adds value as a large grocery store for the students at a decent price, and the Bridge provides entertainment as a movie theater.

New Deck, Smokes, Allegros and more are food options, and bubble tea has even grown from when my friends decided to do it as a project during their college years. And Locust Walk has even undergone renovation... they moved Ben Franklin to in front of Steiny-D for now as they repair his old spot by the compass.
