A big university hospital helped to diagnose issues with friends, and treats countless community members for injuries both great and small.  Research is heavily invested in, and the libraries are second to none.

There are bad professors and good, but that's like any other institution. I can't name a single school which has outstanding researchers & outstanding teachers in every single class, nor will there ever be with the plethora of people that come through here. 

Need-based aid is now all grants, no loans, so that's amazing in and of itself. A huge amount spent on Hey Day, Spring Fling, Homecoming, and more for alumni and students.  Cheap dental work at the Dental School. New expensive housing for people who want to live close to the school, but still the old dorm grad housing for those who don't want to do that.  Museums (the ICA and University Art/Archeology), and displays, plenty of speakers coming through the Kelly Writer's House and Irvine, or small preceptorials that introduced us to wines, dinosaurs, or cuisine in Philadelphia. A restaurant school just minutes walk away.

Anyone remember Walnut Walk? Or Feb Club? Dances & parties, frat houses and off-campus housing.

I miss having everything so close. University City it may have been complete enough for the students to isolate them from the city, but it provided a very stable base to go wandering out to the rest of the city.

review.author: The Krazy Koala K.
review.description: Nice campus. Historical building, green trees, lawn for reading, if u venture out a bit to the tennis court cross bridge, you will find nice track and field and environment there. It's also good to jog along the river. Love the campus here.

review.author: Karen F.
review.description: I attended here in the mid nineties as a grad student at the School of Dental Medicine - and believe me, 3 stars is as generous as I can be.  I was harassed by a sadistic Bay Instructor, chased down Baltimore Avenue by "Hatchet Man" and generally had a miserable experience which may or may not have been the fault of the school.  Meanwhile, I got good grades - but transferred out to escape the scourge of West Philly at that time.  (It's alot nicer there now.)\n\nI have a feeling the undergraduate experience would have been better.

review.author: Phillip Y.
review.description:
CLASSES- UNDERGRAD/GRAD (4 out of 5)

I went here for undergrad in ChE and took a grad course in MSE.  Overall, classes here are pretty good.  Class sizes can be crazy huge for your standard chem, phys, econ, etc.  Competition is also pretty high so it can be daunting.  Profs here ranged from accessible to inaccessible.  At the time, Penn Course Guide was good to rate profs so you know what you are getting yourself into.  Now, I'm sure there are online reviews for classes.

LIBRARY- GENERAL COLLECTION, ILL, EZ-BORROW, PRINTING (5 out of 5)

I can't complain except for the price for borrower's access as alumni.  As a student, it's great but sucks to be an outsider like alumni.  Catalog is pretty huge here and if you can't get it here, librarians can get it for you.  Printing basically sucks now.  Before, I remembered as an undergrad printing everywhere was free with your tuition/fees.  Now, it's nickel and dime you by charging your Penn card like a copy card.  

GYM- REC CENTER, SWIMMING POOL, CLASSES (4 out of 5)

Wow, this place is HUGE.  Pottruck is much larger than I remembered when I was an undergrad.  However, the fees will bite you in the butt since it's optional for grad students.  The outdoors rec center is pretty decent with outdoors climbing clinics.  I found it to be pretty reasonably price and good experience.  Pool is really nice here as well.  Tons of cardio equipment here as well as class rooms for yoga/zumba/etc.

BURSAR'S OFFICE/BOOKSTORE (2 out of 5)

A bit of a nightmare for registration.  Alot of red tape from dept to Eng school to Registrar's Office.  It helps to have patience when registering a course outside your dept.  Overall, not the most pleasant experience and tuition here is pretty steep.  I soon realized after getting the bill- at least my company paid for it.  I had to study like hell for the course to do decent in the class- still it was a tough grad course.

CAREER SERVICES (5 out of 5)

I used career services in the past as an undergrad for on-campus interviews from neighboring companies.  However, I think I have benefited more now with their counselors and mock interviews.  The staff here is great and very accommodating.  There are counselors for each school- Eng, College, Dental, etc.  So, they specialize in all areas which I haven't found from other schools.  Easy to get help over the phone or onsite and help out alumni as well.  I can't say enough that this place is just a huge asset when it comes to career search/development.

VERDICT (4 out of 5)

I can't say that I loved being a student here.  It's stressful even taking a grad course.  However, education wise it is probably the most challenging in my mind.  I had some really great profs who saw my perserverance and kept me afloat when I felt it was unending battle ahead.

review.author: Marissa R.
review.description: Go Quakers. The FIRST UNIVERSITY in our nation - Thank you Ben Franklin!!! And the very first computers - ENIAC - were from Penn too!

review.author: Pamela A.
review.description:
Writing this from a first-year graduate student's perspective. The resources at Penn are amazing. Basically, if you want to do it, you most likely can at Penn. 
The faculty that I have interacted with have been amazing.
students in my cohort have done so many amazing things prior to grad school, which makes classes interesting and engaging. 
The libraries are beautiful. Students usually use the words Fisher and Hogwarts in the same sentence. I have found Fisher to be very quiet and a great place to study. Van Pelt has so many great spots to write papers and read at. Van Pelt also has a quiet graduate student area that you can swipe your Penn card to get into, as well as a new reading room (located just as you walk into the library - to the right), and beautiful views of the city.
The graduate student community here is also a definite plus! There are a lot of events offered to meet other graduate students. Plus there is a beautiful lounge to study in.
I could go on, but to sum this review up - my experience at Penn thus far has been amazing (I know---complete overuse of the word.)

review.author: Nick C.
review.description:
Wharton Finance grad here. Could we limit reviews to people who actually attended Penn? if you've never eaten at a restaurant, your opinion of the food isn't going to have much value.  

Anyway, Penn has a few attractive and historical old buildings, but you can see these with a quick campus tour. Other than that: 

-It's a poor value (very expensive, but State U. class sizes) 

-It has little practical point (what little you'll remember from all those courses a few years later you could have learned by reading a couple of books).

-It's in a dangerous part of town in a lame city with terrible weather. Your sidewalk will thaw out around May. 

-While there are some cool people, it's populated largely by prep school kids whose "parents" were often the older kids who picked on them. This cohort dominates the social scene. 

-It's too big and impersonal for anyone to really care about the lives of its undergrads. Penn is churning out industrial sized tanks of Bud Lite, not craft brewing quality in small batches. They could devote resources to actually mentoring and developing students, but then who's going to pay for all those new buildings? 

Sure, your degree will impress interviewers with Fresno State MBAs, but do you really want to work with dudes from Fresno State?

review.author: Fred B.
review.description:
When looking for an adult game, family game or an educational gift this is the place to go. It's so nice to have a store like this in the neighborhood. Learn, Play Grow, their mission is to change the way people see education by making highly interactive and memorable learning experiences available in a quick and easy way. 

They have hundreds of games, puzzles and brain teasers. ExtraordinaryED has items for for adults and families of all ages.  If you are unsure of what awesome gift to buy when you visit, don't sweat it, they offer gift cards. It's a great option and let's that individual select the perfect item for themselves.

Parking is metered street parking. They are located a block away from the Collingswood PATCO station, and if you have a Patco card bring it in to receive a discount off your purchase.

review.author: Ttww3 3.
review.description: this is specifically for the high school: y'all suck. period. y'all don't know how to actually help your students, so you just ignore them and push their problems under the rug. after my father passed away, MONTHS later, i got called into the consular so they could tell me that they're "here for me if i need help". at that point it was almost the end of school, and passed the point of help. almost  of the staff members genuinely care about the student's mental health, and i constantly hear/see people have breakdowns in the bathroom. i've heard stories of people having breakdowns in the bathroom, and being told to go back to class, instead of sending them to the consular.  also there's dead bugs all over the floor. this school sucks. periodt.

review.author: Charles M.
review.description:
My niece plays basketball for this University. I actually spent a lot of time here when I was in HS while my mom was working on her 4th degree from Rutgers. She didn't want to come alone at night so I would accompany her to her classes. 

My cousin went here from 99-2001 and many other family members. So I suppose we have a long standing relationship with this school and it is a great University with two campuses or more in NJ. I can't speak for thier athletics department because Rutgers football program gets beat by everyone and I've only gone to one female basketball game. But the education is one of the best in the state. 

This campus sits on the waterfront in Camden NJ, one of the roughest parts of south jersey, but they do an excellent job of keeping the campus clean and safe for students. I've never known any of my 7 family members that graduated from Rutgers to ever have issues.

review.author: Wayne W.
review.description: I have just moved onto the Rutgers Camden campus for graduate school.  So far I am very impressed with the organization that they have with Rutgers new Brunswick.   I had gone to Newark Rutgers and they had no collaboration with the other rutger's so when I needed something it was annoying.  Here it is not the case they work well with the other rutger's and it makes things a breeze.  I am living in the graduate dorms at 330 cooper and I have to say they are gorgeous they are four bedroom suites and 4 separate bedrooms with a large living area and two bathrooms to share.  I have not been to any classes yet but have met with a lot of my teachers and they all seem very professional down to earth but professional which is what you want from a professor.  I am very glad they accepted me to come here because I have only been here a day and am amazed at this place.  They make you feel like you are at home with the massive campus all the amenities and security like you wouldn't belive.  If you are looking to finish your degree or try and get another I would recommend this campus.  This is a subjective view as I go here.

review.author: Tyler R.
review.description: I graduated from Rutgers University - Camden.  I go back regularly to help with alumni functions and to provide support with the Honors College and admissions.  This is one of the best academic campuses in the state, and you will learn more here and have access to so many opportunities in the Metro Philly, NYC, and DC areas because of the partnerships and faculty involved. Going here was a great decision, but I wish the university would make some capital improvements to the physical buildings to keep up with other universities. \n\nRutgers-Camden will forever shine on the banks of the old Delaware!

review.author: Julia K.
review.description:
I've been a regular of this establishment since 2009. it is difficult to write about a place that supplies you with the best tools in the world - knowledge; however, I can write about the servants. first of all, don't let the location intimidate you. it is Camden, but the "beautified" part of it. Rutgers police is everywhere and unless you are completely careless you will be safe. for example, I wouldn't walk back to the parking lot at night, but rather take the Rutgers bus. 
some buildings are better than others. do not expect Princeton-U feel when you walk down the halls. generally the place is fairly neat and clean. 
the administration is on and off: accounting people are helpful and pleasant; general administrative offices are... not so much. 
now, for the quality of education. there are some incredibly talented professors that will make you love your college experience. some adjunct  instructors are okay at best, but generally I am very satisfied with the quality. 
the career services folks are knowledgeable and helpful. 
the cafeteria is actually very good and  reasonably prices. 
the library is a little bit of a mess, but that is only because it's been under construction for the past couple of  years.
there is life on campus, thanks to different events and trips, etc... 
generally, it is a good bang for your buck.

review.author: Mike C.
review.description: This school sucks, there's never anyone here and when they are here their always in the bathroom when I'm trying to poop. The gym sucks Rex activities are non existent. 12 people live in the dorms so don't bother. You really should just go to Rowan at this point

review.author: Nick P.
review.description: I have been to this military installation quite a bit. I am not stationed on this base, but have taken my DA photos here, and utilized the exchange, commissary, and wellness center. I like this base, and you will see a lot of officers walking around. Most of the time, they just want to get to class and not be bothered.

review.author: Ally G.
review.description: Never thought I'd learn how to use a bugle. Thanks US Army War College. Minus one star for lack of #2 bathrooms.

review.author: Liv W.
review.description: If you're looking for a place to get depressed and sad come here. Their food at the cafeteria will make you so sick that you can't eat for days. And you will go broke because they will steal all of your money yes. Although I do love my friends here. I also really like the Professors especially Professor Heard. I'm only giving Dickinson two stars because I love the professors. But I will say this I would like my money back from the cafeteria Dickinson do better your students are hungry and poor!!!!!!

review.author: Elissa O.
review.description:
Full disclosure: I am the parent of a newly-admitted DC Freshman. I also was accepted years ago at the Dickinson School of Law, which is un-related to DC but sits at the edge of its campus. As such, I've been to Carlisle a number of times over the past 30 years, both as a prospective law student and as the parent of a DC student. Here's my "review" of Dickinson College and the surrounding town/area...

Beautiful campus, strong alumni network, including extremely successful alums like the CEO/President of LL Bean. Numerous awards for being a top-rated college as to sustainability. Responsive staff. Small student to teacher ratio. Encourages students to find their passion, so interesting combinations of double majors and majors/minor abound, and students don't declare their major until Jr year, I believe.

Encourages study abroad and for a somewhat unique statistic I think, Dickinson states that 60% of its student athletes do so, with the coaches' encouragement! 

Dickinson is what it appears to be, "family" to its alumns and students. Extremely supportive all-around. 

Location is close to Harrisburg, the Commonwealth's capital, as well as an easy 1.75 hour ride to Phila area (85 miles in my case!) as a straight shot down the PA  Turnpike!

One comment stated this is a boring school with nothing to do. That's ridiculous. There are attractions within an easy drive, _lots_of activities on campus, and a growing diversity of students. And, to callously call the surrounding area as being full of "red-necks" is nonsense. As a former diversity trainer with a major Fortune50 company and within the USCG Aux, that statement really jolted me.

The folks in Carlisle may be more rural in background than say someone from a city or a suburb near a city, but they are welcoming and friendly. Judging an entire community based on some interaction had with one or two (perhaps) is simply unfair to the community as a whole).

Go Red Devils!

PS To YELP: Why the heck would you NOT recommend the 3 "Not Recommended" 5-star reviews that were well-written, thoughtful and gave details upon which the reviews were based? And, from both students and parents! I don't get it! If they were included, DC would have a near 5-Star rating which is more in-line with what I've experienced via the many alumns I've met, both at DC functions AND by pure chance in the "big outside world" where they had no reason to be biased in their view...i.e. I met them via normal, everyday encounters via my job, etc!

review.author: Deegan B.
review.description: The quarry stinks! This small campus dining service has average service and won't even toast your bagel! You want some late night eats? Don't bother the oven isn't working. Definitely not your mothers cooking. Academics are pretty good. The lax guys are hot af.

review.author: Full C.
review.description: College administration that values eco-responsibility. Most buildings are LEED gold and platinum, the president's Mercedes runs on frenchfry grease, and they have partnerships with the local community working on farms and making biofuel. \n\nStudent population is mostly caucasian and from the NorthEast. Tuition is relatively high, but if you're interested in sustainability, Dickinson College has degree programs and outlets for experience in this field.

review.author: Alice Z.
review.description: A nothing college in the middle of nowhere. Boring, boring, boring. Nothing to do, nowhere to go. A nothing campus surrounded by a nothing town full of rednecks. Put this on your list as your safe school and pray to God that you get admitted somewhere else.

review.author: Allison D.
review.description: My son and daughter both attended this school for several years, and my daughter continues to attend. We have had a very positive experience with LEMS. The teachers truly care and build a relationship with each child and family. The director is very flexible in regard to working with your schedule needs. I especially love the diversity of the students and teachers at the school and the focus on teaching kids about other countries and cultures.

review.author: Matt M.
review.description: After looking online for a place for my two little ones to attend daycare in the near future we were sold online from the security that was in place, curriculum that was taught, and all the smiling children. Therefore, my wife and I drove from another state to take a tour and were told by our daycare to do it unannounced to get a true feeling on how they interact with the kids and with you. We entered to building... Yes we entered the building and walked around for 15 minutes looking (without a code) and did not run into a singleness member. This should have been our first warning to run but I gave them the benefit and tracked down a worker due to no staff being in their offices either. The staff member said they were celebrating a event and said tonsit and wait and the director would come out and speak with us. So we waited for 15 minutes and subsequently I went and tracked down another staff member and asked if the director had time for us today. Finally the director came out of a room and seemed irritated to even speak with us. She said no tours could be given today. I asked if we could come back later in day to do a tour and her response was no I have to pick my kids up at 3. I then asked her if anyone else was available to give a tour and her response was no. After this attempt my wife and I left. Please don't bring your kids to this daycare due to safety concerns with anybody being able to walk in /out unannounced and the unpleasant staff that could possibly take care of your kids.

review.author: Poonam S.
review.description:
this is review for Little Einstein, Bentonville AR.

Pros first:  My child's first school and he never cried, always happy to go, he had great teachers in Junior preschool, though he was in the process of potty training the teachers accepted him without pull ups ( which is just wonderful), as usually schools would prefer pull ups till child is not fully trained.


Now the cons: it doesnt have any streamlined curriculum that is followed but each week is dedicated to a particular theme and activities are developed around it.  
During December 2013, after my son spent like nearly 4 months in junior preschool,  the school reshuffled its classes and surprisingly my child was pushed from Junior preschool ( 2- 3 years ) to early preschool (19- 30 months) though he was just 3 weeks short of 30 months.  There wasnt any  prior intimation, nor were parents concerns invited. I mean how can you demote a child to a lower school program, there is definitely some big difference between the two levels.   I observed that the children in early preschool were mostly exposed to television and showed stuff like Curious George ... 

Though we have relocated and thankfully out of the class otherwise i would have to wait for my child to go to Junior again only if there was any vacancy again.  So weird !!!

The teachers, esp Ms Becky, junior preschool was great... however the school management is not very friendly.

review.author: CardsFan 1.
review.description: I was very disappointed in my experience with Little Einstein Montessori School in Bentonville. I will speak for the infant/toddler rooms only for this is where my child was at during his enrollment. There is high turnover with the teachers, inconsistent structure, sporadic or sometimes no updates on child throughout the day on the "daily connect app", dirty rooms, children sharing their belongings, etc. I had a Tylenol bottle come up empty after just buying it! Was this given to my child? Other children? Nobody seemed to know anything about it. My child came home with a huge scratch on his arm and there is still a scar from it. Again, none of the teachers knew what happened. I would not recommend this place for your child especially if you are like me and want to have good interactive relationships with your child's teachers and be informed about your child at all times.

review.author: Thomas N.
review.description:
WARNING! THIS REVIEW CONTAINS A PHILOSOPHY.

A review of any college is perhaps more a ridiculous proposition than reviewing other things because, in addition to the usual vagaries of opinion, a college of any size will not be experienced by two people in remotely the same way. Are you a student (whether traditional or not; whether serious or not -- I'll not say, whether intelligent or not), an office worker, administrator, instructor, or someone attached to the college in some cooperative capacity, or a combination of any of these? NWACC is large enough to encompass a plethora of experiences. So, a review that begins, "My algebra teacher was a bore," wouldn't begin to characterize the potential of any community college.

As for me (who functions as an employee, one that has worked at other community colleges and universities), I enjoy the campus, which is nicer than many other campi (noun, Latin plural). That is important; I like clean lines. The library, which is always the clincher, will more than adequately support most any academic endeavor, for both student and professional, with friendly assistance. As for the education, accessibility is stressed, I have clearly seen, which is good news for many. And, out of the classroom, college culture is promoted in a variety of ways, for those who require that.

What else can be said? Yeah, that one guy cut me off in the parking lot. Rotten teen drivers! And, they don't offer the Vietnamese courses I would like to take ... maybe even throw in a field trip to Saigon. Oh, well. Still, I'm a fan.

review.author: Don M.
review.description: I've been working on a degree at this college, and I can definitely say that I am a fan of it. The instructors and advisors are very friendly and knowledgeable, and the scheduling can be done around some schedules along with the ability to take online courses. The campus is kept up pretty well, and even offer umbrellas to travel between buildings on campus when it rains. They also hold awesome events very often, including their recent Halloween fun.

review.author: Spencer F.
review.description:
Caution: this place is a deposit mill. By all means, putting a deposit down should not mean that your child is guaranteed attendance at any day care...unless you are lead to believe so by their staff. 

I put a deposit down nearly a year ago following voluntary assurance from the team that it would be no problem to get our child in before my wife was planning to go back to work. 

Following this, we never once received any follow up, any indication of a broad timeframe of when our child could start, or even an idea of where our child is on the waiting. 

We've had much better luck at many of the other local daycares.

review.author: Courtney M.
review.description:
We are SO happy here!

Both of my boys attend here, one in the infant/toddler program and one in the Pre-K. We have been so thrilled with the quality of care our boys receive. They love being dropped off and I love that I get updates all day on their routines and learning via the ap. The transparency is wonderful for peace of mind. 

My children are learning so much and thriving. They are loved on and cared for and happy! I would (and do) recommend this school to anyone looking. 

I also love that with my older sons food allergies they are so aware (everyone from kitchen to directors to floating help) that I never have to worry - they treat him as if he is their own and make all accommodations. 

Being away from them is hard enough so knowing that they are safe, healthy, happy and enjoying their day is so wonderful!

review.author: LaDonna F.
review.description: I work at Cadence of Rogers and have for 4 years, I love our school, parents and children. I couldn't see myself any other place.

review.author: Madeleine S.
review.description: This is my favorite school in Rogers. I teach extra curricular activities all around Washington and Benton county, so I see how all the preschools are ran. The teachers and front office staff are the friendliest you can find, and the teachers are all extremely kind and attentive. The kids are happy, the facility is clean. It's really the best! If I had preschool age kids, they would be at Cadence in Rogers.

review.author: Deb B.
review.description: As I continue to get pictures and updates through the day it just brings a smile to my face and I feel like I have to write a review to let others know about Cadence as well.  First off, yes I will agree with Rachel J's review below about the previous asst director, however since we started she left about a month after and things couldn't be any better!  I get updates on my little girl throughout the day and pictures as well!  I love all the art projects they do with the little ones and book reading, exploring, playing outdoors, etc.... No matter how young, they have a curriculum planned daily for your little one.  I don't feel like I could even come close to matching all the fun things they do here with my little one.  It seems like she comes home weekly learning and saying something new.  I just love it!  And the teachers and staff here are OUTSTANDING!  You can tell they genuinely care for your child and not sure how, but everyone knows her by name, office staff and other teachers she's never had.  \n\nI will add, no one paid me to write this, just an honest review because I know how hard it is to find GREAT childcare.  I think I toured over half of them in the area and if it's not the BEST then it's not for my little one.  Thanks Cadence staff for being so great!!

review.author: Shanah C.
review.description: I highly recommend Cadence, I have two kids at this school.  The Director, Twila, is very open and listens and treats my kids with so much love!  The teachers are wonderful and in comparison to other schools it seems like there is minimal turnover with the lead teachers.

review.author: Chastity M.
review.description: My son has been here for a year and we LOVE it!!!! Can't speak highly enough of the teachers!!

review.author: Danielle L.
review.description:
My twins started at Cadence Academy on opening day and we have been impressed from the start! From the moment we walked in, we felt the warmth, care, and professionalism that encompass the entire center. Annalyn, the director has done a wonderful job getting to know all the students and families and making us all feel welcome and part of the Cadence family. Any questions or concerns I've had have been immediately answered or addressed. 
All of the teachers have great attitudes and genuinely care about their students. They provide plenty of one on one time throughout the day, and even extra TLC when needed. Miss Abbie, the lead infant teacher does a fantastic job and is passionate about her babies. She has worked with my twins through several transitions already and continues to teach them new skills everyday. We would love for her to move to toddlers with them!

Overall, Cadence Academy is a top notch school in Rogers and comes highly recommended. I don't know how anyone could have anything negative to say about this school and the staff!

review.author: Samantha D.
review.description: Our family has nothing but good things to say about Cadence Academy! The staff is there because they truly love and care for children - this is not "just a job" to any of them and it undoubtedly shows! The curriculum is amazing, facility is safe and spotless, and the staff - especially the Director - are all approachable and easy to talk to. This is where you want your child(ren)!

name: McCann School of Business and Technology

review.author: Sarah G.
review.description:
I decided to join this school because I wanted to learn my job and get right into the field without having to deal with the extra stuff at an actual college. Unfortunately, this place was WAY more hassle than just taking some extra nonsense courses. Let's list the problems:

1: They force you to take a "College Math" course. To begin, this is not a college math course. This course is a 9th grade course which involves very basic algebra, conversions, and geometry. The school gives you no chance to test out of this class unless you continually berate them and express your anger that you're being forced to pay $1,000 or more for a course you absolutely do not need. I was even told "Yes, you'll have to pay that money, but at least you'll get an A." Had to have three discussions with them before they allowed me to pay $100 to test out, which I aced with no sort of studying prior.

2: A majority of their staff is out to get you and are about as useful as teachers as a rock is. They had a computer teacher that knew nothing about computers and may have been on drugs. This teacher was kept for A MONTH before they finally bothered to listen to the complaints from the students and gave her the boot. Their one law teacher forces you to be your own teacher and does whatever she can to make students fail. You could be dying in the hospital, finally recover, and she would refuse to let you make up any work because it was your responsibility to keep up on it. Even if you were dying. And she refused to tell you about any of the work since she didn't plan any or her classes and just decided to wing it every time. But that's your fault for almost dying, so you deserve to fail the course.

3: They have zero respect for the military or their students. I gave my teachers almost a two month notice that I would be leaving to go to Texas for a basic training graduation. Only one teacher, who was responsible enough to plan his classes, was able to give me the work I needed to get done and allowed me to get it completed before I left. The other teacher, mentioned in my last point, in fact, didn't give me any work until the day before I left. Then she had the audacity to have a MASSIVE two-part, 130 point assignment on the last day I told her I would be gone. She refused to let me make that up, of course. Then after getting incredibly irate at her, she kicked me out and THREATENED A POP QUIZ, which cannot ever be made up, and she actually went through with the threat. I went to the two highest ranking people at the school, who both belittled me and refused to acknowledge that the teacher did any wrong. Even after I admitted to doing wrong on my part and accepting my punishment for what I said to the teacher, the completely stood by the teacher. One even made reference to me going to a BASIC TRAINING GRADUATION, something that happens once in a lifetime, as "Well you were the one that chose to go on a vacation."

4: They have a dress code, but do not stick to it, nor do they care about enforcing it. When I first started going there, they were business casual only. Now you can walk around in short and flip flops with your breasts almost hanging out, and nobody bats an eye.

5: Gum under all of the desks with little care from staff when this was brought to their attention.

6: Their computer classes are worthless and a waste of money. Especially the ones where they are teaching you to type when a majority of students already know how to type well. They allow no test outs for this, therefor you end up wasting THOUSANDS of dollars, again.

7: Most teachers accept sub-par work, so if you want to put half effort into something and get an A, this place is for you. Only the English teacher, who I greatly respect, expects you to improve and to do great work. She's also the only one who really teaches you what you need to know, and teaches it well.

8: They tried to deny multiple law students their degrees because they insisted that their externships were not good enough, even though the lead of their program approved it.

9: They have multiple security violations at the school, such as a multitude of light bulbs being out. When brought to their attention by the students, they responded "It's not in the budget."

10: They overcharge for the sub-par education they are giving you.

If you truly care about your future and care about learning, then this place is NOT for you. If you want to get a degree with minimal effort, minimal gained knowledge, and a massive hole in your pocket, then this place will be wonderful for you.

review.author: K G.
review.description: As a current student of this school - I have to urge people to not attend. i am finally able to transfer out -- and I found a school who will accept my credits! 5 more weeks. The instructors here do not care about teaching; they do not care if you learn; and they sure don't give a d**m if you succeed and graduate. They care about the money -- and that is it. McCann purchased my school in the middle of my education and since then -- problem after problem. I began when it was CTC in Monroe, LA and half way through they changed to McCann. They changed the classes to 5 weeks long with four hour classes - and then load you up on classes and hope you fail so they can charge you for the class again. My admissions representative lied to me (typical) when I enrolled. She told me it was an Associates of Sciences Degree -- and that any college would take my credits. I called over 100 colleges in the country and found a handful that would. I haven't learned anything in any of my classes. Please, do your research BEFORE you enroll in a school. I am transferring to Southern New Hampshire University where they actually care about your education; they are a non-profit; and the Degree is an ACTUAL DEGREE. An Associate Degree in Occupational Studies? I shall pass.

review.author: Jimmy S.
review.description: Great place great Quality care for your family all the staff are great nothing bad to say about it you can leave your children there and feel great about it love this place

review.author: Phillip G.
review.description: They're in the business of taking enrollment fees when they knowingly don't have space to take on more children. They're essentially selling a product they don't have. Granted the place must be good if they're always full, but they completely lack integrity when it comes to getting new families to sign up. We paid the $100 registration fee and were told that they would have an opening in a few months. We've waited for more than a year and still haven't gotten in. I tried to work with them on getting my money back before posting anything, but it doesn't matter that they blatantly sold me on something they don't have. The only thing that matters to them is the contract I had signed which protects them from their dishonesty.

review.author: Stephanie F.
review.description: Well worth the wait. My daughter is absolutely thriving and loves going to "school". She eats a variety of healthy foods for breakfast, snack and lunch everyday (and I don't have to do a thing). The staff put the children first always. We toured several places and this one definitely stood out above the rest.

review.author: Amy D.
review.description: ALWAYS ask about teacher turnover rates. In the time my child attended, more that 6 teachers were hired and left. (In 6 mo.)  Turnover rates in daycare can be an issue. In this case, it was ridiculous. The blame for that should be directly placed on the director. As an educator myself, I say run, don't walk away from this place!!!

review.author: Maggi M.
review.description: I can't express how grateful I am to the director Whitney for always making the time to answer any questions or concerns we have regarding our son Nodin. Nodin has been with this location for about 4 months now. He's 2 1/2 and an only child. We moved here from Denver in August and it hasn't been the easiest transition for him. Enrolling him at La petite Bentonville Ar. has been the one of the best choices as parents we've made. We recently started potty training and genuinely had no idea how much work time and stress can accompany that life change. Our son who has always slept through the night started getting up multiple times each night as he curiously wanting to grasp this new toilet concept. I more often than not drop him off at La Petite Academy after having had almost no sleep  and every morning Whitney and I go over his progress and she gives suggestions and tips I would not know otherwise. She is completely dedicated to every child in the building and having someone to answer my questions, tactically make me aware of potential mistakes, while still making me feel validated as a mother has truly been a blessing. I trust her and the staff completely while my son is i their care  and to me that's priceless.

review.author: Kasey L.
review.description: I love this daycare/academy! My son is always coming home with new things to share!! The teachers are great with them. I also love that they have a speech therapist there so that I don't have to leave work to take him to his appointments, they do them right there!! If you want a choold care that will provide for your child, I would totally recommend this place!

review.author: Celeste C.
review.description: Your child will be safe here. They are careful and \nsend lots of daily reports. The child to caretaker ratio is too high, however. I believe they need more teacher/caretakers per child.

review.author: Jennifer T.
review.description: My 2 year old daughter loves going to school every day. This is her first daycare and at first she had a really hard time at drop off, but they are really good with her and it's getting better and better every day. She has SO much fun when she gets there and they send updates and pictures throughout the day. Everyone knows her name and she is well loved. The director is outstanding. Whitney knows each child by name and obviously loves them and her job. Her educational background ensures that they are learning age appropriate skills and having fun doing it. I couldn't have asked for a better place to put my precious daughter.

review.author: Elizabeth S.
review.description: La Petite is wonderful with our son that was diagnosed with autism 2 years ago.  They allow the ABA therapists from Thrive and the OT and SLT therapy teams to work at the school.  The director and teachers really work together with the therapists to help our son get ready for kindergarten.  Joe was not speaking many words when he started, and his language has increased and his skills have improved where he can attend a general education classroom next year.  La Petite is truly a safe, fun, educational, and perfect place for our son to learn and make friends. I don't know where we would be without them, and they have changed our lives for the better in our family.  Thank you so much!

review.author: Sally L.
review.description: What a fantastic place for children!  My pre-school grandson came to visit during a week when I had to work and I decided it was time for him to try a daycare setting to prepare for Kindergarten.  I met with La Petite Director Misty Hopkins and after an excellent discussion little Ivan was ready to start the next business day.  After his week he said he made LOTS of friends.  Overall he had a really wonderful experience and now he's better prepared to start school next month.  Thanks Misty and all the ladies at La Petite!

review.author: Vince C.
review.description: Place WAS great. Permanently closed  now after COVID.  Too bad.  Owners / staff were friendly and helpful, and prices were very competitive.

review.author: Casey C.
review.description: Nice guys, good prices. Great selection! It's a small shop, but it's full of some good stuff. They do transfers as well.

review.author: Tony R.
review.description: Excellent friendly people.  A decent selection and prices are fair.  Been there about a dozen times and every time they were friendly and helpful.

review.author: Michael W.
review.description:
There are so few alternative educational options in Bentonville. There are plenty of private schools, but very few that are not parochial. More importantly, very few who are as tolerant, inclusive, and focused on raising children to honor peace and civility and to appreciate the natural world around them.

Montessori is not daycare. It is not even your traditional school. Children at Walnut Farm are empowered to do things for themselves, and to study that which interests them most. In addition to several well appointed Montessori classrooms they also have a few unique features such as an outdoor classroom where children are learning life skills including gardening and caring for animals. The school also has a natural playground with features literally carved from the forested hillside.

I see my little boy growing into a confident, warm, caring, and intelligent young man at Walnut Farm. He loves to read and do math. He is fascinated by and in love with every kind of animal. He loves his teachers and his classmates. 

When kids reach school age, we rely on the school to mold them into the people we want them to be. Schools have the kids from 8 to 3 most days, leaving just 4 or 5 hours with their parents. If they are going to play that big a role in the development of my child... then I feel strongly about choosing a school that not only does a good job educating my child, but also teaches him to grow up tolerant of the many differences in people around the world. 

They take children from toddlers through around the equivalent of 6th grade.

review.author: Max B.
review.description: I'm a parent with a son at Walnut Farm for almost two years.  He loves going here and is excited every day.  My wife and I are amazed at the progress he's making and are impressed with the teaching and administrative staff.  I'm a strong advocate of the Montessori method and Walnut Farm has been at it for a long time... they know what they're doing.  When we meet former students or even older kids at the school now, we're so impressed with their maturity, awareness and capabilities.

review.author: Nene W.
review.description: We moved from California over a year ago. My daughter has been attending Walnut Farm as a preschooler for the present school year. We absolutely love the school and it's staff. The teachers are truly special and amazing! They are witty, kind, knowledgable,compassionate, creative, and have such a wealth of experience. We have a lot of experience with having been through 6 preschools between both of my kids. We love the involvement with nature and the lack of electronics in the school. My daughter learned to read in the past year, and her confidence is amazing. She has also learned great conflict resolution skills (communication) and real life skills (ex: setting/clearing the table). This school has a great peaceful & positive enviornment  that is very welcoming. I am so grateful that they are here!

review.author: Terri W.
review.description:
My family wanted to find an educational alternative for our son that was more than just a school. We wanted a place where the person he is going to be can be nurtured. We wanted a place where his natural curiosity can be fostered. We wanted a place where tolerance, acceptance, and peace are just a natural part of the day. 

Not only is he receiving core curriculum (reading, writing, math, science), but he is exposed to rich extras such as Spanish, nature education, life skills, art, and music. Children learn to investigate and research from a very young age. The learning is sparked by interest - so the child is more invested in it. 

The Montessori method truly is remarkable and Walnut Farm does a lovely job of presenting an authentic experience. The classrooms - both indoor and outdoor - are led by caring, passionate teachers where the students are encouraged to engage with the lessons. They are empowered to learn and given the necessary tools to do so.

If you have a child between 18 months and 12 years and want more than just a traditional education, consider a visit to Walnut Farm. It is my greatest hope that you see what my family saw the very first time we set foot on the campus.

review.author: Charlie Ann H.
review.description: I have one child at this school and will be enrolling our youngest soon.  I love the school and their curriculum.  It really gives the children freedom to explore what interests them and therefore stretches their attention and learning.  They have an outdoor classroom with a teacher outside at all times for instruction.  I think that is amazing!  There are two trained teachers in each room.  They offer Spanish, art, and life skills along with your typical school subjects.  We are very happy with the school and so is our child.

review.author: Pat L.
review.description: I love going there - it is so fun. I don't paint very quickly and I'm not always really great at making up my mind. They are super mellow and I always end up getting just what I want.

review.author: Trash G.
review.description: We went to create-A-Palooza for our ninth wedding anniversary. We actually go by the traditional wedding anniversary gifts so we thought this would be a fun thing to do together The experience was wonderful and the customer service was great. There was a large selection of pottery to choose from to paint, and of course every color was available. This is a great thing to do for people of all ages! And we have cute keepsakes for our ninth anniversary.

review.author: Holly W.
review.description:
My daughter and I visited yesterday and had a great time! When picking your piece of pottery, the price includes as many glaze colors as you'd like and firing. No additional fees like some other places. We spent several hours there finishing our items. The staff was friendly and very kind and patient with my seven year old who lost interest in finishing her project after the second coat. The other customers were also very kind. While we were there, they hosted two parties and several other guests but we still had all the supplies we needed and staff to help when needed. We are excited to return and pick up our items and to revisit with my other children. We will definitely go back!  
They recently moved to this location in High st from the Plaza Mall. The building is very old and they have done some reno/restoration to it. 

Update: 
We picked up our items and they look fabulous!! We will defiantly return!

review.author: Beth G.
review.description: This is a great place for Girl Scouts to earn their badges. We did a brownie painting try it here and now the Junior Drawing badge.  Mrs. Griffith did a great job hitting all the badge requirements.  The cost is reasonable for a troop too.  We paid less than $20 per kid for two projects.  We'll be back when they are Cadettes.

review.author: Melly H.
review.description:
What a wonderful place! When visiting family in town for the holidays, we decided to have a family painting night together. We were all a bit overly ambitious in picking out ceramics to paint (we were first-timers and didn't know what we were doing). As such, we ended up needing to come in for a total of over 7 hours over the course of a few days to finish our projects. Karen, the owner, was so very patient with us and incredibly kind. She made sure that we had all the tools and paints we needed to make our projects. She had exactly the right balance of being available to answer questions and give us additional information without seeming in the way or overbearing. She even offered to let us borrow some paints to take home to work on our pieces outside of the studio's open hours. That kind of generosity and customer service is a true gift.

Beyond that, the ambiance of the place is perfect for unleashing an inner artist. As a very old building, the original features of the home have been marked and dated, making it fun to wonder about what the 1860's original wall-paper must have seen in its time!

The prices for the pieces are incredibly reasonable, and without additional sitting fees or firing fees, the fun-per-dollar ratio is a fantastic one. We also found a fantastic deal on Living Social, making the experience even more of bargain.

In sum, I would highly recommend Create-A-Palooza to individuals, couples, families, and anyone else who has an interest in being creative!

review.author: Ashley Z.
review.description: Really fun place to paint pottery. They provide all the tools and clean up the mess! Lots of fun. Can't wait to go back and try it again!

review.author: Mhn W.
review.description: Found them due to the penguins, and, boy, are we glad we did!  Staff was very helpful - both in person and in responding to emails quickly.  No extra fees, which we appreciated.  We had a wonderful time painting our pieces, which turned out great, and look forward to returning soon. Yay, penguins!!

review.author: Sach O.
review.description: Our youngest child has been in pre-school at Lifeway for 2 years. Our family's experience has been so powerful and wonderful that we are transferring our oldest child to Lifeway. There is such a positive, passionate, and Christian atmosphere at Lifeway. We love it.

review.author: Earlene H.
review.description: Engineering is passionate about sharing their engineering knowledge with children. They have great teaching techniques as well as subject content. I highly recommend this program!

review.author: Dot W.
review.description: Great place for kids to learn while having fun. My son had his 8th birthday party here and loved it - and it was stress free for me!  Would highly recommend.

review.author: Victor W.
review.description: I have known the owners for years and they are wonderful! My seven year old daughter loves attending birthday parties there. This is a top notch place!

review.author: Beth P.
review.description: This place doesn't even deserve one star. They messed my hair up so badly I left.  First I was FREEZING I asked the " instructor" can I please go outside I'm cold while my hair was proccing. She bit my head off, I asked for another cape sweater something. When the product starting burning I had enough and asked to just rinse it out.  She rolled her eyes ( which had way to much and to dark of shadow on them)  she bit my head off, to which I replied you are a very rude person to which she responded YOU ARE RUDE! JUST floored I could not get out of there fast enough. When I went to pay which I know I know I should not have.. 80 for them to screw my hair up. When I got home she had tacked on an additional 17 I'm assuming a tip??? Which was not deserved and is highly illegal. I did take a picture.. If u value your hair DONT go here.

review.author: Kiara G.
review.description: Decent prices. Services are done by students. But its surprising how they dont know the steps to follow in any process. Sometimes it's a guessing game and somethings its a trial and error. This is very disappointing. Overall experience is ok. Will think twice to revisit the place. Students are extremely friendly.

review.author: Elizabeth G.
review.description: Let me start by saying...I know it was stupid to go to a beauty college to get my hair done but I went in there for an eyebrow wax and really liked the girl. When I couldn't get in touch with my regular stylist, I decided to give this girl a try. I have two-toned hair, blonde on top, red on bottom. I wanted a highlight and trim. Long story short...the little girl MELTED MY HAIR!! I understand that can happen and I tried not to panic. She had to cut off ALOT of hair to try her best to get rid of the melted hair. Did a deep conditioner...my hair still looks a bit like a cotton ball. That's not the worst part...the woman instructor along with one of the owner's sons came over and told me that they would waive the fee for the deep conditioner so I'd only owe $41!!  I told her I wasn't paying to have my hair melted to which they responded "that's theft of services" and threatened to call the police on me. The owner's son proceeded to insult me saying my hair was fried before I came in. Let me mention that I get at least 2-3 compliments a day on my hair...it was a little dry because I bleach the top, it was far from fried and I typically do the color myself. I have never ended up with melted hair. Ironically, I decided to do highlights on the top because I wanted LESS damage. I ended up calling the police myself when they told me if I left without paying they would get my license number and have me arrested. Turned out....I had to pay...I'll have to take them to small claims court if I want my money back. You can get a messed up hairdo anyplace...it happens, but the way they handled it, unapologetically and insulting is absolutely appalling. NEVER AGAIN...they're HORRIBLE!!!!!

review.author: K C.
review.description:
If I could give this college zero stars, I would. 

The fact of the matter is that the college itself, its roots, its staff, its president, all point back to nepotism, favoritism, preference because of popularity, and hypocrisy. 

Any review you read that talks about these things is 100% true. Do not, I repeat, do not attend this college. If you are not related to anyone of importance or are rich, you will be treated like trash.  

Please, do yourself a favor. Don't go to this college. This school is dying all because the leadership and President won't change their childish ways. 

They are racist, hypocritical and do not want poor 'nobodies' at their school. 

Oh, don't forget how his grandsons have full-ride scholarships to the college. Yet he and they will always deny it. 

Avoid this trash college.

review.author: Thomas M.
review.description: Administration is littered with racist, homophobic trash piles. It is not a healthy environment for education nor development. CBC is a danger to society.

review.author: Cat F.
review.description: Such a fun experience ...free game, enthusiastic fans, gorgeous facility, A+ college!

name: First United Methodist Day Care & Pre-K

review.author: Han T.
review.description:
Parents BEWARE! This is advertised as St. Mary's "Preschool" although it is nothing of the sort. They are registered in New York State as a DAYCARE, not a preschool, and they'll do everything possible to hide this fact from parents. They therefore have no standards to uphold, and your kid will learn nothing - not shapes, letters, colors, etc. There is zero kindergarten preparedness happening at St. Mary's.

The "teachers" are simply babysitters, and if you think it's impossible to be 'bad' at being a preschool instructor, you're wrong. I'm certain that my kid's classroom babysitter has an intellectual disability herself, with her vacant stare and utter inability to communicate to other adults. It's just not something you want your kid to become accustomed to all week.

The kids just watch TV all day, although they may let them outside to use the very small jungle gym if it's warm out (e.g. basically never). Once in a great while, they will send my kid home with a craft project that they spent maybe an hour doing. The rest of the time is spent with the basic daycare routine of snacks, naps and playing with toys.

If that's all you're looking for, then St. Mary's is probably the same as any other daycare. If you want your child to be ready for kindergarten though, this is NOT the place to send him or her. 

St. Mary's is not a preschool. Don't make the mistakes we did. STAY AWAY!!!

name: United Theological Seminary and Bible College

review.author: Sarah C.
review.description: i love this school more than anything! I've attended west side for the past 13 years of my entire school years. i just graduated this May and I can't even begin to describe how amazing the teachers, staff, coaches and students are! all the teachers want is for you to succeed and they show that very well. i have always felt at home here and will miss it more than anything!

review.author: Sue P.
review.description: All kinds of private lessons, small groups lessons, and workshops,  Watercolor, Drawing, Cartooning, Crafts, RE-cycle projects, Professional Development for Teachers, Ukrainian Egg decorating, Calligraphy, Perspective, Proportions of Figure, Proportions of Face, etc.  Fun and friendly atmosphere.  Have an Art Party that's a step above.

review.author: Quincy E.
review.description: Great university to attend!  Buildings are updated and new! Instructors are easy to reach and offer good advice! Student life is fun and a lot of opportunities.  It's a beautiful area with lots to do. Hiking, camping, kayaking, and Mt. Nebo down the road. My young adult daughter loves it, although she doesn't like to study so much!

review.author: Randall K P.
review.description: A great university. Has had impressive, quality growth over the years.  Nice facilities on campus. The faculty gives their students personal attention. Students are not just a number here.

review.author: Daniel P.
review.description: Nearly the entire campus needs to be power washed, it's looking very old and dirty.  The physical appearance of the campus is hurting.

review.author: Patrick C.
review.description: Much improved student environment compared to when I was a student there. Seems like they are building constantly but they need to improve their Witherspoon theater; you would have thought the people that designed it were only 4ft 8inches tall because the seats are uncomfortable with not much leg room.

review.author: Joseph M.
review.description: Don't expect much help from the various offices. Financial Aid will be especially annoyed with your presence. Watch out for the woman who looks like someone locked her in a tanning bed for days. She's got a bug up her butt.

name: Kinder Kollege Learning Center and Daycare

review.author: Josh A.
review.description: Silence in the Jungle is another phenomenal show put on by Melonlight Productions! The level of acting, lighting/effects and overall script took you deep into the heart of a spooky jungle. The cast showcased their talents and got me scared right into the Scary season! My partner and I got drinks downstairs at Brews which added to the overall wonderful date night we had! Can't wait to see their next production!

review.author: Tom R.
review.description: My wife and I attended 'ANNA' last night and were so impressed. The actors were so captivating and had us on the edge of our seat the whole show. The show is based on a story about a young married couple who unknowingly move into one of the most haunted houses in the country. The writing is truly brilliant as is the choreography, lighting and setup between sets. The way the dancing actors incorporate dance into a few scenes is also astounding. No spoilers, but this is a must see in Eureka Springs. This show will be going on until November I believe. Can't wait till we have family come to visit us here so we can take them and see it again!

review.author: Noel J.
review.description:
This group and performance were like nothing we have ever seen. Raymond and Emma, founders of a dance studio that moved here from Colorado, have created seasonal performances in Eureka Springs before but this is the first time we have seen them and their acting/dancing crew. They now have a hit show and are letting local residents and vacationers alike see what they can do. And they can do much more than you can imagine!

The performance we attended was 'Anna.'It is a performance that runs like a traditional three act play, presenting a young couple who just bought a large house on a huge piece of land. The house has a history, and the history slowly sinks its claws into the couple and their friends and family. I will say no more on the plot, but you are up close, inside the house from the opening scene, so prepare yourself. 

The actors all live out these characters naturally and can bounce between eras in dress, voice and style in the flick of an eye. They are "around" the audience at times, making you feel more and more as if you're inside the house. They use light, and sound, and excellent special effects timing, to make you squirm as you begin to realize what's happening.  While it is not a musical, music figures strongly in, as does their expert dancing. This makes 'Anna' like no other live stage performance we have seen, and we were blown away. The dancing feels natural because it is integral to the story and the transporting of the audience across time and into the heads of the characters.  You will love it. Well done, Raymond, Emma, and the rest of Melonlight! We will see this again if it is still playing on our next trip. And if you have something new, we'll be sure to see that! Thank you for creating something great in this lovely town.

review.author: Allan H.
review.description: Absolutely everyone there was just as nice as could be and made my wife and I comfortable and very welcome. They didn't treat us as good customers, they treated us more as friends, and it was very much appreciated! Quality of instruction was amazing and as someone who can not dance (and knows it very well) and therefor is extremely self conscious, they helped me get over that in a hurry. I went from embarrassed to dance in front of my wife to doing the Thriller dance with their group in front of thousands of people in less than a week. If you get a chance and have ever even remotely thought of taking a dance class, you owe it to yourself to go by and take a lesson here.

review.author: Dominik D.
review.description: This is a humble, but completely effective local college. They have the local conference center right on the property and it's only a short drive from the new LifeShare.

name: Cossatot Comm College U of A
SW Arkansas Planning and Development District
Cossatot Community Collge of the Unvrsty of Arknss

review.author: Leslie H.
review.description: This was a good stop on a rainy day. We decided to do a tasting, but we found that there were not a lot of the wines we were hoping to try available to sample that day. They had approximately half of their list available to sample. \n\nWe found a couple that we enjoyed. The employee working with us seemed knowledgeable about the products.

review.author: Brien M.
review.description:
I didn't find much to love but everyone's wine preference is different so my experience is likely to differ from yours.

Regardless, we had a free tasting that was fun and we left with 3 different bottles.

Heads up: the new tasting room is at the back of the property behind the previous building and at this time there is no art on display.

review.author: Heather W.
review.description:
Wine in Arkansas? I know what you're thinking... but hear me out. This is some award winning stuff! And they use their own local grapes (winning)! The tasting is no cost, and bottles are extremely reasonable. If you buy two bottles, you get a free wine glass. Wine is $6 by the glass.

A big fan of wineries in Europe and South America (Italy, France, Chile, Spain, etc.), and my beloved Sonoma, you aren't going to get the same type of experience or aesthetic here. And at the time I went in, COVID was (is) still a concern, so the tasting was different than you'd usually get - and disposable cups were used instead of glasses which would definitely allow for a better taste of the wine.

Now, I am an equal opportunity wine drinker. I tend to gravitate more toward the reds, but it was the whites that were the show-stoppers for me here! 

Overall, with the reds, I found them to all taste more like "light" ports. I did take a bottle of the Cab Franc home, and it was alright, but I didn't love it. For the port itself, I liked the Ozark Strong a bit more than the Big C (which is a tawny). The Sweet Spring which is a Chambourcin was my favorite, good finish.

The star? The Vignoles which is a French hybrid from the Keels Creek Vineyard and another nearby farm (I believe the owner said it is in Hindsville, not too far away). It has some really nice Pineapple notes. It's not toooo dry, but dry enough. I love this with spicy chili or tacos. I think it would also go well with some smoked fish or chicken. I also enjoyed the Chardonel and could totally taste those green apple notes. The Melange was pretty sweet for me, but the finish I really liked.

All COVID regulations were followed. The owner wore a mask, kept physically distanced and any type I removed my mask to sip, he stepped back even more. Another couple came in and waited in a sitting area.

5 stars for being low key, a great white and local!

review.author: Darlene F.
review.description: My husband and I came for a tasting planning to bring home a bottle of Arkansas wine. We've never had wine from this region before.  When we entered the shop, it was empty except for one couple at the bar. They were doing a tasting. The woman behind the counter told us she would be with us as soon as she finished with the couple. We waited thinking that she would do a pour and then help us while they tasted their selection. After about 8 minutes, it became clear that she was going to finish their ENTIRE TASTING before even inviting us to sit down. At that point, we decided to just order a glass and not do a tasting. We approached the bar again to ask about a specific wine and to place an order for wine to take to a table.  Clearly irritated, she firmly told us that she would be with us when the current couple finished their tasting, so we left. We live right in the middle of Texas wine country, and visit wineries frequently and have NEVER experienced anything like this in Texas, California, Italy, or anywhere else. Tasting room staff are typically able to work with multiple customers at the same time. If this woman is too challenged to serve more than one customer/small group at time, management should consider getting her some help or replacing her with someone who can actually serve customers and make sales. We were disappointed to not have experienced any Arkansas wine. Some of it looked very interesting. If you decide to go here, I hope your experience is better than ours.

review.author: Hec A.
review.description: Good wine, great price, nice seating, great art. For those reviews that say the hostess was rude, I feel a little conversation on the tasters to engage the host goes a long way. She was nice and personable once you engaged in conversation, it's a two-way street. Overall delicious wine and great experience!

review.author: Kendra C.
review.description: My Mom and I stopped in this quaint little winery on our first day in Eureka Springs.   They offered free wine tastings and $5 glasses of wine which seemed like a great deal.  The tastings were pretty good and fairly informative but the Sommelier was extremely standoffish and not engaging at all.  She seemed very irritated by us when we were just trying to make polite conversation.  She seemed to want to hurry though it although we were the only ones there and I about 1 hour before closing.  We did end up buying a bottle of wine and probably would have purchased more if she had been a bit more welcoming and a better salesperson! The gentleman that checked us out (perhaps the owner?) was very nice, however.  We decided to get a glass of wine and enjoy it on their nice little patio after the quick tasting.  \nI've always enjoyed wine tastings in small wineries like this and love the conversation that usually comes along with the tastings.  Perhaps she was having a bad day?

review.author: NoCheeze F.
review.description: If I could give less than one star I would \nThe lady giving the tasting was rude and a wine snob - posted on Facebook too -  I am not a wine connoisseur by any means - I just like what I like  -  after being treated like I was nothing I walked away and I was NOT going to part with any of my money to help her out - sorry for her that she had such an attitude since the day before we purchased several bottles from each of 3 wineries we visited - AND tipped our hostesses really well for pleasant conversation and the great explanation of each wine  -  took 5-10 minutes of being a nice human being to win my business that this place couldn't and didn't provide - I wouldn't send my worst enemy here!!! Will NEVER return!!!

review.author: Vicki C.
review.description: Stopped briefly as we had little time. Certainly enjoyed Visiting with Kelly while enjoying a rose and a port.

review.author: Kathy K.
review.description: We did the wine tasting. We are not sommeliers but we know what we like and liked almost all the wines HOWEVER the wine expert who gave us our tasting was a wine snob. She couldn't wait to get rid of us. She sized us up the minute we walked in the door and was cold through the entire experience. I've reached an age to just ignore people like that but today I was speaking to another tourist and she had a similar experience and so I decided to do this Yelp review.  The business is for sale and I think it could be very popular and a must do destination if the hospitality can be improved. And by the way, we did buy 4 bottles of wine but will NOT be going back.

review.author: Azile Y.
review.description: The somalier's mask kept falling below her nose, even though customers were having to take their masks down to do the indoor tastings... She needs a better fitting mask. We weren't comfortable taking our masks down inside so we asked to do a tasting outside, and she was nice enough to oblige- which she probably can't do when it's busier, but it was pretty quiet at 4pm when we visited. The wines were pretty sour I general, though the muscat and port were nice (and I'm not normally a sweet wine drinker). Positive marks for customer service, but the slipping mask was a huge red flag for us. We realize that establishments can't always control what their customers do to take safety precautions for COVID, but there is never an excuse for staff to slack on this.

review.author: Megan R.
review.description: Was not expecting much upon entering this location but was actually blown away with the tasting.  It was $5 for a tasting of maybe six wines and it included a take home wine glass.  The tasting was very educational. We even got a chocolate kiss to pair with one of the wines.  Ended up buying two of the wines we tried, so the tasting was worth it. Don't pass this location by.

review.author: Lara H.
review.description: We had a lovely time at this very reasonably priced tasting. $5 got us a sample of 7 wines and we got to keep the glass.  The building is homey and has a great little art gallery.

review.author: Jay S.
review.description: Great winery with an excellent selection of wines from locally grown grapes. Nice selection of both red and white wines from dry to sweet. Wine tastings available include souvenir glass. Wine by the glass also available to relax on their patio.

review.author: Thomas D.
review.description: Stopped in and throughly enjoyed the tasting.  Daphne was a great hostess explaining the wine, but doing so with humor.  Enjoyed looking at the Art too.  Highly recommend this winery when in Eureka Springs.

review.author: Kai H.
review.description:
I heard that Arkansas has seven wineries.  So here's 5 of 7.

Keels Creek is one of the newer Arkansas wineries and a bit outside the more 'traditional' Arkansas wine town of Altus.  What you find here is something akin to a microbrewery of wine making as they focus on producing small batches of very high quality wines made from local grapes.  $5 allows you to taste six wines and keep the wine glass.  Only drawback is that, so far, they don't have any distributors so a trip to the winery is necessary when you need a bottle.  

Worth stopping by for the excellent wines.

review.author: Cory G.
review.description: I was pleasantly surprised by the service and friendliness of the people running this winery.     We arrived after the listed closing time but were welcomed and given a full, attentive, knowledgeable wine tasting.   During the highly informative session, the nice woman who conducted the wine tasting was stung by a bee (No, I'm not kidding) that had managed its way into the room.   Yet she continued the wine tasting without missing a beat.    The poor bee did not survive even though the kind lady had tried to capture it and set it free outside.     We bought several bottles of the wine after taking a short tour of the art gallery.

review.author: George R.
review.description: Wine tasting was pleasurable, but pay to taste 7 wines w/glass - small ($5) or large ($8) included.  Several of the white wines are acidic with a slight vinegar after taste.  Wasn't a bit hit with us as compared to Missouri wines.  The dessert wine we tasted was the best one we liked among the samples.  Owner helped on exchanging our bottle of wine for something different, which was appreciated, but one of the other workers was unwilling to assist.  Probably would not stop in again.

review.author: Amy B.
review.description: $5-$8 for a wine tasting. You do not select the flavors it is whatever seven they have open. Combining the alcohol is about half a glass. You can purchase sargento cheese prepackaged containers but otherwise no food options. The winery is also a gallery. It's $5 per glass of any wine you tasted after otherwise you have to buy the whole bottle where prices were around $16.

review.author: Buck M.
review.description: We came for wine tasting. Very knowledgable staff. We now look at wine totally different. I didn't know it was such a chemistry to wine making. We loved the embarrassed and viva eureka we both excellent to us and we bought a bottle of both. They also have art hung around for sale from several artist. Really enjoyed the trip. Will definitely be back here often.

review.author: Dennis M.
review.description: Spent a fantastic rainy afternoon at Keels Creek! The wine was delicious, we hung out and worked on a jigsaw puzzle drinking wine and hanging out with the staff...and met the owner/operator. So very glad we stopped!

name: Presybterian Medical Servcs Hd Strt & Erly Hd Strt

review.author: Drinny F.
review.description: My child began late last year and the beginning this year my child was assigned the same teacher and classroom. School was great until my child said he was afraid to go to school. My child said his teacher hurt him. An investigation was done. There are cameras in the classroom, the playground and parking lot.  The investigation was concluded and the teacher has returned. Unfortunately, we have have lost faith in the school.

name: A Gold Star Academy & Child Development Center

review.author: Rosa V.
review.description: after complaining about my child being neglected and put in danger they told us we needed to leave stating I made them nervous (I wonder why)they left my child in throw up laying on her back and when I came in to check on her they lectured me she was choking and left in a full diaper and I took a picture of it and was told my child and I had to leave after I reported the woman sitting there doing nothing but coloring my child had a bad reaction to formula when my child is strictly breast feed they threw out all my babies breast milk out and when we were told to leave they threw all my child's things in a garbage bag I was told by the teacher that another mother was complaining to them about them over feeding her baby and I watched them give that baby formula when that poor baby was only breast fed like my baby This is the worst place ever it really should be investigated when I came in to get my refund they kept it all and only gave me partial please do not take your kids here please believe me this is such a terrible place they hide a lot of stuff from parents about there kids u know this place is bad  when the secretary up front uses chew and spits in a can How do u neglect. 2 month old baby and when they are called on it they throw u out it's all about the money here

review.author: Vicki W.
review.description:
We hosted a large motorcoach rally recently in Farmington, NM and had occasion to meet Dr. Teun Fetz and his Symphonic Band.
What a treat!! Ages range from 14 years of age to 80 years of age in this Community band. You can tell the love and willingness to work for Dr. Fetz with this group!
They played for over an hour and that was not long enough!!
It is so encouraging to find the Arts still being taught in our schools. 
Next time our group goes to Farmington, this group will be invited to come and play for us!

review.author: Camila A.
review.description: Worst place I ever worked or studied. Shaddy place and the HR team does not care about its people. Will throw you under the bus for any little thing. You will feel like you are about to be fired all the time.

review.author: Jorge R.
review.description: I love the instructors. Awesome people. Only one or two have been difficult with communication. Other than that they're awesome.
