However, I call it the hallway, where everything is done for registration and student debt. This "hallway" is full of difficulty and they make it hard to get things done. One person really helped me and she was able to walk me through every station. I realize everyone has their part in the process, but it gets tiring when everyone just passes you on to the next person over and over again. I feel bad because the lady that helped me I had a bad attitude towards at first, but she was literally the last person I spoke to after all the chaos. It's not an excuse to act that way and I feel bad for it. I just wish all the employees down that hallway were as proactive as she is. Hopefully things change next year and I can change my view on this school as a whole.

review.author: Caitlin A.
review.description:
I attended this college online for their veterinary technician program.  The program itself was great, and the professors were amazing.  I attended the Fast Track labs where you good with the professors for a weekend with 11 or so other students at a farm in Texas and learn/perform your large animal skills.  I was super stressed out about it since all my experience in the field was with small animals, but they (Mrs. Black, and Dr. Wright) were great teachers and were very patient with us.  They are what all teachers should be like.  Sherry Hair, the academic advisor, was always very helpful whenever we had phone appointments, and you really feel like she cares about your success, just like the teachers do.    

But....  The school itself was difficult to work with.  These courses are very competitive to get into (which is understand). When the courses open up, you have to be by a computer to get a seat (especially towards the end of the program).  There were multiple clerical errors on my account that on 2 separate occasions caused me to not be able to enroll in the classes I needed on time. The system literally would let me put my courses in my "cart", but would't let me enroll and told me to contact administration.  When I called them regarding the issue (the same day courses opened up), they told me that my mailing address was wrong (it wasn't, they've been mailed me things in the past).  When I told them it was correct, they opened up my ability to enroll in the courses, but it was too late and the classes were full.  I had to monitor the seats every day until someone got dropped for non-payment.  

Their financial aid department messed up my aid EVERY semester.  FAFSA actually denied me aid once because they filled out the form so sloppily (that is actually when they told me, and they sent me copy of what they were sent).  Whenever I'd called and no one answers, I'd leave a message and never get a call back.  One week I called them three times and left messages every time, and I never got a call back.  When I finally got a hold of someone, they transferred me to someone's mailbox, and I'd leave a message there only to be ignored there too.  Finally when I spoke with someone and told them that they messed up my paperwork, they told me to just come down next time to fill out the paperwork.  I live in Arizona.  The school is in New Mexico.  I shouldn't have to drive/fly 400 miles because they can't fill out a form correctly.  The last semester or two I didn't even bother applying for financial aid because of the hassle and put the tuition on credit cards because I'd rather pay the interest than deal with them.  My last semester I had to call multiple times to get a hold of someone regarding my transcripts.  

The quality of this school (at least the veterinary technician program) is great, but forget it if you live in a different state.  You will have a hard time getting anything done if you have to call the front office for anything.  Whenever people ask me if they should look into this school for their certification, I tell them no and that the program is great, but the school itself is hard to work with and it's like pulling teeth to get anything done.  I have to give it 2 stars because if I had to do it over again, I wouldn't just because of the front office issues.

review.author: Laura D.
review.description: Great positive atmosphere! Inspirational music and conservative ideals have kept us here for more than 8 years. Dancing is fun!

review.author: Charley N.
review.description: This is my daughters 4th year dancing at Shining Stars Dance School. We love it! Great, positive atmosphere. Christian enviroment. My daughter can't wait for dance class every week. All the teachers are awesome.

review.author: Max A.
review.description: Great Sewing resource in the Fort Smith area, friendly and knowledgeable staff at a very convenient location.

review.author: Craig G.
review.description: Best Defensive Driving School in the River Valley. The great thing about this school is that it is not owned by a cop! Awesome instructor and not boring at all. I learned a lot and had a great time.

review.author: Ramona H.
review.description: Save your money for a real college. Also, get everything in writing and keep it, even after graduation. The college is not what it used to be, even a year ago. It has greatly changed with the new chancellor. You get what you pay for.

review.author: Tami M.
review.description: The post by Diane L was recently brought to my attention.  It is exceptionally misleading and emotionally charged.  Tara Mishra has consistently provided his students with superior instruction.  More than likely, this is a disgruntled student or acquaintance.   Apparently this was written in Norway, which really raises suspicion.  In conclusion most negative reviews are unreliable.

review.author: Diane L.
review.description:
Great But if You are in IT WATCH OUT for Dr. Tara Mishra

I found my overall experience here to be (above my expectations) and the majority of the faculty to be extremely down-to-earth and helpful. However, there was one faculty member in particular (Dr. Tara Mishra in IT) who freaked many of us out and I have been wanting to complain about him for years, but kept my mouth shut, because he has this way of gagging people via subtle intimidation tactics. If he felt like you were under his spell, he would make disparaging remarks about woman, certain races and faculty members who seemed to be on his perpetual shit list. He would then add humor to his statements so it wouldn't seem too horrible. Regardless it was unprofessional and many of us lost respect for him. He was constantly making bizarre comments about how his computer is acting like so and so in the department, his ex - wife or how the system was as inefficient as the chancellor. Sometimes students heard him howling at people on the phone before he realized someone was outside his door. At times he would try to drag others into some drama he was instigating with other faculty or students. That was way out of line!! 
If you did not concur with him he would act like an over-inflated peacock and brag about his stellar academic history and position. This would be followed up by tales of his big shot professor brother from Australia who had powerful 'connections' so he doesn't have to worry. I perceived this as if you don't play my game, I'm going to seriously mess you up. 
Well I will be leaving the country PERMANENTLY, off the grid for awhile so I am taking the opportunity to get this off my chest! If his big shot brother is that desperate to track me down for speaking my mind, he has more issues than 'Dr. Mishra'. Dr. Tara Mishra, Its pathetic I have to use an alias to make this review, because I know he probably would track me down.
Future students watch out for this guy! He will try to get to know you by finding out the troubles in your life and offering you saint-like assistance. If you make the mistake of telling him your problems or accepting help from him (I mean other than typical academic advising). He will carefully file all this information away and be especially nice to you. Gradually he will try to reel into some political game he is playing on campus. I have heard of him going as far as coercing people to outright lie for him (even in court). I believe he only does this to select people with whom he's been able to play on their vulnerabilities. I think that because many people who do deal with him have never heard or seen anything to give them a negative impression. If you want to have an academic relationship with him, your fine. He's pretty smart, but NEVER tell him about your sick grandma, your impoverished parents or ANY personal problems. If you do you will be the proverbial frog in water that gradually reaches boiling and become his puppet.

review.author: Ron N.
review.description:
Pretty good cafeteria food. I loved the fried chicken strips with a cup of cheese. 

Oh my gosh their cheese. Its like runny, but sweet, but cheesy!

Over-all actually a pretty good education. Despite the ghettofabulousness.

review.author: Payal K.
review.description:
We moved to Fort Smith for a new project and my son was suddenly exposed to a completely new environment, food , language and culture. 
The staff is extremely helpful and friendly. His teacher Ms Teresa helped my son settle down in no time. He loved school and all his friends. 
The director of the school Sherry is extremely approachable and a very loving n caring person herself. 
We have now since moved to another location and another state but my son still misses his friends and teacher at Cavanaugh.
Good Luck u guys You are doing a great job We miss you

review.author: Daniel S.
review.description:
This is a very money-hungry administration and they do not treat people appropriately. During the corona virus pandemic they wanted to continue to charge all students full tuition ($1423 per month per child or $2846 total for our two kids). Our children are ages 2 and 4, and The New School essentially serves as an educational day care for our family. They would not offer a refund for the period of time that school was out so I got a lawyer involved. I have no problem paying for services as long as services are being received. They ultimately waived the payments in question, but I just found out today that they also cancelled our children's enrollment for the 2020-2021 year without our permission. We never asked to have the children removed from the school. The head of school (Nancy) will not even communicate with us directly anymore. When we reach out with questions about enrollment she simply says that only our lawyers can communicate going forward. 

We have several friends whose children are there currently, and they are having similar issues. One couple in particular wanted to withdrawal from the school electively due to safety concerns surrounding the pandemic. Even though school has not officially started for the academic year, they were told that if they pulls out their children that they will still owe full contract price for the academic year (roughly $15,250 per child) because it is after July 1st. Hopefully, you are starting to get the picture. 

We enjoyed the school itself and the teachers. I had no problems with the education component of the program. However, the money-driven nature of the school poisons the environment. It is not worth the ultra-high premium that they require for tuition. Maybe the K-12 experience is difference, but the contracts they have for the early childhood education is absurd. They are more interested in taking your money than doing what is right. 

I have since gladly taken my children elsewhere.

review.author: Bill U.
review.description: Love the university and how it is embraced by the community. My son loves the town and school as well. Looking forward to visiting several times over the next few years.

review.author: Loosey B.
review.description: Great bookstore on campus to get some Razorback gear. Football stadium was under construction but the campus is nice to walk around.

review.author: Talara T.
review.description: Our family loves Art of Motion! Our daughter is 3, and is usually pretty shy and clingy when Mama is around. AOM takes the kids to the studio, sans parents, and we can watch them practice from the monitors in the waiting area. She enjoys class much better this way, as compared to our experience at another studio. Class is always on time, and her coach Cortney is really great. Costumes for recital are here well ahead of time, and of great quality. Overall, we have had an exceptional experience here, and highly recommend AOM!

review.author: Kevin V.
review.description: My daughter just started at The Art of Motion this year, and she is really improving! The quality of instruction there just can't be beat. The teachers have really helped my daughter's confidence, too. You can tell that they love teaching and take their job as a role model very seriously. We're so glad we made the switch!

review.author: Daryl A.
review.description: For the best hair cut or stylists Hair Design is the place to go. Yes they are students but well instructed and supervised. I have been using them for over 15 years. You will be greeted be with a welcoming smile. They are  Students eager to develop their skill in a competitive profession. They listen to what you want. After consulting with certified instructors they focus their attention to you. As young adults learning; starting their chosen career in Hair Design. \nI use the same 'artist' till she graduates. No where can beat the price. Even adding a cash tip to the practicing stylist I leave refreshed. The school of Hair Design is top of the line for. They are the best.

review.author: Zoe D.
review.description: Place is full of uneducated stylists who don't know how to properly do hair besides a basic trim IF THAT. The place is crawling with racists and can't teach anything useful for you to purse a promising career. Do not go here.

review.author: Tabitha E.
review.description: If you are looking for a quality education in cosmology, do not waste your time here. Look elsewhere even if it seems too "branded". Career academy of hair design seems to spend its students tuition on insuring they don't learn much about modern, fashionable hair design. Instead it hires people who graduated from their school in 2019 to teach! You will not be taught by experienced professionals, you won't be taught much that will make you a serious competitor in your field, you'll have to do that yourself here. If you only want to learn the most basic and OUTDATED concepts of hair, with little guidance, this is the place for you. Not to mention a few of the staff members could really use a lesson on racial sensitivity. A lot of poor behaviour is let slide in this place, a lack of professionalism, and an uncomfortable environment for students of color. The price of tuition does not reflect the quality of education at all. I was overall disappointed.

review.author: Lyla W.
review.description: Greek life is great. Colleges are great. Horrible living, absolutely no parking. parking is given to freshman that already live on campus...

review.author: Matthew P.
review.description:
This is solely in regards to their online schematics. They clearly do not know how to create a student-friendly internet experience as well as with advising. It is a system to set students up for failure with appointments for advising being far apart and scarce. No matter how early you get on advising for example, there will be a line (which is fine, we are all struggling to get in), and then it will kick you out of line if you aren't glued to the screen for who knows how long. 

The campus is beautiful, the professors are generally friendly, but the online navigation for students is just TERRIBLE. It's as if both students and faculty are trying to figure out how to connect online. 

I just want to make it possible to do it myself, but I've got to navigate through a sea to meet the people before I can edit a schedule or change minds about majors.

review.author: Luiz L.
review.description: Terrific school, one thing that I have always wondered though is that if the university is that of diversity than why have I never seen anything that promotes males or every race as a whole? As I walk through the halls of any building I notice that the only things ever promoted consistently are organizations focusing on LGBTQ and women, a long with a few minorities here and there. Aside of that note, has anyone ever noticed how LGBTQ has there own parades and is clearly nurtured, but when it comes to Veterans Day or something that includes making the ultimate sacrifice there is little to nothing.

review.author: Avery C.
review.description:
Going to this school was a miserable decision, professors, advisors, & employees treat you like another number out of thousands, there is no individuality, and the lack of communication that comes from everyone involved with this university has caused an unruly amount of stress for both me and my parents. 

It is over-priced, a party school, and everyone at this school has been overall unhelpful. 
Transferring was a GREAT choice.

review.author: Bruce K.
review.description:
Woo! Pig! Soooie!

As the bumper sticker says, my daughter and my money go to the University of Arkansas. Mom and I got a brief guided tour from her this weekend, walking through the campus, the bookstore (I bought a Razorbacks t-shirt and a hat), the student union and the building where she attends class.

U of A is a major school, founded in 1871. As you would expect for the school where the arena is named after the brother of one of Wal-Mart's founders, there is also the Sam M. Walton College of Business. Tyson is a major employer in the area, so they also have a large college for agricultural science, specifically related to poultry (chicken) sciences. The Razorbacks have reasonably decent football and basketball teams that play in the Southeast Conference.

review.author: Cierra B.
review.description: I went to game day to watch the red and white game and one of the security guard was so rude. We were sitting down with everyone around us. And the security guard said we had to get up and move, so we get up and move but a little kid is standing up and other people are in the same spot that we're just in, but they never had to move. I'm very disappointed in the way that the University Of Arkansas security had become. It makes me never want to come back.

review.author: Ed S.
review.description: Well I'm a tenured professor here so I may be a bit biased but U of A is a great school for its size.  The state of Arkansas will never have the resources that Texas or California have to lavish on their institutions of higher education.  Keeping this in mind I believe it's accurate to consider Arkansas an excellent university and a great value.

review.author: Daisy D.
review.description: Wooooooo Pig Sooie! Razorbacks! We were in town for graduation weekend and had some time to walk around campus and check out the place my nephew called home for the last four years. It's a relatively small and easily walkable campus. While you can get to some of the outskirts of campus, you can't drive through the center which makes it very pedestrian friendly. \n\nNo shyness from the local 'empires' with both Tyson and Walton being big players on campus. Still being a relatively 'small' school in the SEC it has some 'perks' that other bigger schools don't necessarily see. Would have never really had a reason to see NW Arkansas or Fayetteville, but glad I can add it to my 'been there, done that' list.

review.author: Alexander S.
review.description: Do not recommend riding a bike in the rain from the science and engineering building to hotz hall

review.author: Cole F.
review.description: Be careful ever taking any of their distance learning courses.  I applied and never received any confirmation of acceptance or enrollment.  They said they sent me an email.  A single email, nothing in the mail, not a second email wondering why I had not participated in a single lesson, nothing.  Then these crooks send me a bill after the course time had expired and threaten collections for a class I never knew I was enrolled in.  I thought, well they are reasonable people, once I explain and they notice I didn't take part it will be obvious that I didn't know I was enrolled.  NOPE!  (what school doesn't take at least a portion of tuition up front anyway?)  There is no way I could have known that they enrolled me.  It is like Jed Clamped is running the distance learning department.  They basically extorted me for $350.  Look elsewhere.

review.author: Marklin M.
review.description: Suey! Is all that comes to mind when I think of this place. Man I stayed in Rogers AR for about 5 months back in the day and got to spend a considerable amount of time on the campus with the players on the basketball team who were just good 'ol stand up southern boys. Everyone on campus was so friendly and the campus is very spacious and clean, I couldn't help but fall in love with it. Lucky for me Football season came along before I left and some locals took me to a Razoback's game against Univ of Miami! Great game and I never heard so many people chant SUEY in my whole life and those who know me know that I am an avid pig collector so I was right at home. If you are in Razorback country and especially if you are a sports junky like me, this must go in your to-do list!!  Oink Oink!!!

review.author: Veronika S.
review.description:
I attended this University during 2004-2005 so probably a lot has changed but my experience was pretty good. There were students from all over the country and all over the world. There was a class where I knew two people from high school and another friend named Paul. Most classes were lectures, which I like because I sit there and take notes and there's so many people that it's hard to start drama. My government class was in a theater and the person that sat next to me was the security at the art gallery and he was so nice. Some classes were small but they were fine too and I met someone from Detroit and we did group activities in that class and they went well, no disasters.

An advisor told me that even though the zoology department was gone I could still go to school and then my degree would show that I graduated with a degree in zoology. The last time I saw an advisor she told me that it was untrue. I failed biology twice (I know zoology major fails biology, but trust me I'm better at animal sciences) and then gave up which is sad because I wasted so much opportunity and the scholarship I received and fell behind to the point that I've been in an out of school, well when I moved to a new state the University said they couldn't find my transcript and I did read about the University losing school records, maybe now that digital has been around for a while they can find my transcript. I don't get the Razorback thing but I've moved around my whole life so I don't get school spirit in general. I felt that this school (I could be wrong) was moving towards becoming a sports school or training place for future athletes, which is ok.

After the head of NORML came to speak the NORML Representative at the University was expelled and a lot of people thought it was because the University wanted to lessen NORML's power or get rid of the organization.

This was the last place where I had solid friends but some people can become violent quick without any provocation, the cops used to stop my boyfriend and I every time we would walk to the store- never got violent thank God but it happened so often that one time a cop waved at my boyfriend, my boyfriend couldn't get a job as a bagger at a grocery store because he has long hair, there's also the whole clinics are bad and make women promiscuous. There are some people in the area that still have old-fashioned beliefs and it's not just the older generation but the older generation passes it on to the younger generation. If someone is not used to this then it can be a real shock, it was for me. I was forced to move to the area by my dad so the negatives were probably ten times worse. If I had a choice I would have gone back to my birthplace to finish high school and lived with my Grandma, not that there's anything wrong when I went to Fayetteville High School but that's another review.

Sorry this is so long I do that on Yelp reviews, I wanted to write this review because I wanted to write about a good school experience because on my other school Yelp reviews I come off as some kind of nutjob.

review.author: Laura A. D.
review.description: I am rehabbing in Statesboro with son & daughter-in-law.  They took pity on me being house bound & took me to Board & Brush.  I am not a craft person and was apprehensive. However, I cannot say enough about this place.  What a great time I had.  It was so much fun.  If you're like me and severely challenged in this area, do not be afraid.  The owners and the staff are more than helpful.  You can purchase beer, wine, soft drinks, etc which is a plus.  They have tons of items to chose to make, along with paint, stains, and all the other implements involved.  I was very pleased with what I made.  Will I be going back -- you betcha -- and more than once.  There was a sign I want in my kitchen, and another one for my bedroom, and then there was the clock .... Guess I'll have to move here.

name: Charter Conservatory For Liberal Arts & Technology

review.author: Donald V.
review.description:
Growing up in New York, and having attended one of the  best school districts in the state ( Three village schools ) I have very high expectations for my sons education.  Of course when I started school......the federal BOE was not around to make things worse.  That being said:  My son attended the "Government school system" in this state from the 1st ( grade ) grade.  This was nearly equivalent to the Pre-K program  in N.Y.  
      We were so proud of his academic achievement, as his grades were all excellent.,  As he progressed through his "Government" education,he proceeded to fall behind my standards as a parent.  By the 5th (fifth) grade, it became so intolerable for me.  He could barely read, and his writing more closely resembled Egyptian Hiroglyphs ( ? ).  It was beyond maddening.  As if this wasn't enough, the bullying was horrendous.  And because my son is "white" he was labeled as a "racist" because his bullies were black ( African American -PC) we were informed that, that fact alone precluded them from being predudice ( what kind of mallarchy is that?)  That's when we found CCAT.  

     Since the 6th Grade ( when they start to accept admissions ), my son has excelled in almost every subject, espescialy math ( thanx Mrs. Powers ), he has a love for history, and politics ( believe it or not ), and actually gets up in the morning without whining!!! imagine that.  An education that I can be proud of for my Son, without the grief of Government schools?  I'm sold........I would even be happy topay for the education that my boy is getting........but the school wont let me.

     Thank you Dr. Kathy, and the entire CCAT team.

                                           Sincerely;
                                                           Mr. and Mrs.  Donald Vincent

P.S.  Mr Benji.....You should keep ridding........LOL

review.author: Ashley L.
review.description:
Ah, Hollins oh Hollins :).
 I am at the undergraduate university as a senior, and have spent the past years building my resume through their connections with internships, and trying to find my way with a liberal arts education. It's been a bumpy ride, but having faculty and stuff always kind and respectful to its students has made it worth my time here. The professors work hard to provide a great education and challenge each student's individuality while teaching students how to work cohesively in groups. 

Even if you don't come to attend, come along and check out the scenery especially during the fall and spring! I highly recommend it for events and photo shoots!

review.author: Tom B.
review.description: Everyone at Hollins can sleep sound tonight. Barney Fife chased out 3 high school girls who went there to take homecoming pictures because of the beauty of the campus. The girls were dangerous for sure?!  So anyway, the campus is safe tonight.... Oh and the admissions department just lost three potential applicants who are local and have over 4.0 gpas.

review.author: Sarah J.
review.description:
Beautiful private women's university. Walked around the campus during Thanksgiving break and some of the places were open although there were very few staff and students hanging around for the holiday. Large, spread out, but with a small town feel, sort of like the cities surrounding. The entrance is pretty and the campus is hidden behind it over the hills. 

We did get to go in the library, which is fairly outfitted but not as large as some university collections. It was a gorgeous space overall! Definitely had that old world scholarly feel.

Rating system:
5 stars = I'll drive across town specifically for this, and rave to all my friends about it!
4 stars = Would recommend visiting.
3 stars = Average, acceptable, positive.
2 stars = You might be able to drag me here.
1 star = I will not be returning.

review.author: Jana S.
review.description: I went to Greenbrier about 7 years ago. I have mixed feelings on this place. The staff and the girls were all amazing, friendly and caring. However the actual treatment aspects were not  great what so ever. They barely teach you how to handle your emotions and feelings. The staff recommended a wilderness program because I was not doing well in their program. I was not able to do well because they didn't teach me anything and were less than helpful. The school is barely a school but the teachers are kind. Now I can't say how well the program is doing  now since it has been such a long time. But I hope they have put some changes into the Managment as well as their therapeutic aspects.

review.author: J B.
review.description:
I am a very private person that shuns social media and normally would not post anything on Yelp or any other site.  However, my wife and I read reviews regarding "therapeutic" boarding schools during a very stressful and troubling time when we had no answers at home (whatsoever) and seemingly no options with my increasingly troubled teen daughter.  The Yelp reviews (both positive and negative) about Greenbrier Academy were really meaningful in compelling us (as a family) to visit and consider the program as an option and so - after my daughter graduated from a year-long program a few months ago, I am writing this review during a Parents weekend at her new college-prep school where she is absolutely glowing and thriving.  My daughter's hard work and desire for a better life coupled with the Greenbrier Academy program and excellent staff (everyone at the school) made this all possible.  Worth every penny.

As you read these reviews, please understand that the GBA therapy curriculum focuses on the entire family dynamic (and not just the troubled teen girls).  This seems to be an unwelcome surprise to some parents who are simply unwilling to admit the part their behavior plays in an unhealthy home environment that is often the root cause of teen trouble.  If you are a parent and you do not love your kid enough to drop your ego and work just as hard via therapy to change your own destructive behavior then do everyone a favor and admit this up front.  Greenbrier can handle the rest if you do the work and admit that it's time to listen to experienced professionals construct a customized treatment plan to help your daughter figure things out for herself and set her on the path for self-reliance.

There are no shortcuts unfortunately.  You have to do the work.  But the Greenbrier program and Mike Beswick's excellent and experienced staff make all the difference.  You can sleep well at night knowing that your daughter is safe and that the most important things in her life at this moment are being addressed in the most fair and impactful way possible.  The results speak for themselves.  Worth every penny.

review.author: Patty M.
review.description: I can't say enough good things about Greenbrier Academy and how they helped my family.  Our daughter had struggled for years with ODD and anxiety.  Our family walked on eggshells daily and we couldn't even enjoy a meal together without a huge blowup.  We enrolled our daughter as a last ditch effort to help her, but the staff at Greenbrier made us realize that our whole family needed help!  Mike and Greta, you saved my family and I will be forever grateful.

review.author: Dorit F.
review.description: Our daughter's experience at the Greenbrier Academy has been truly life altering. Our 16-year old daughter suffered from anxiety and depression, self harm and suicide attempts that lasted 4 years and worsened over time, despite many interventions and therapeutic assistance. When we decided to enroll her in the Survival Skills Wilderness program at Trails Carolina, it was because we reached the end of the road. We were afraid she would not reach her 17th birthday. Our daughter graduated wilderness with a renewed sense of self esteem and a positive perspective on life and life's worth. Going from wilderness to the real world would have been challenging still so we decided to enroll her in the short-term program at the Greenbrier Academy for Girls in West Virginia. It was the best decision for us and for our daughter. The Greenbrier Academy offers excellent therapeutic and academic programs with experienced teachers and seasoned therapists, people who deeply care about the girls and their academic and therapeutic success. The program is headed by 2 amazing directors: Head of Guidance, Michael Beswick and Academic Director, Lowell Galford. I cannot begin to express our appreciation and gratitude to these 2 individuals and their teams. Their level of care, their expertise, their experience and the efforts they undertook on behalf of our daughter were tremendous. They succeeded not only in encouraging our daughter to turn her life around and change her misguided perceptions and beliefs, but they also assisted the whole family to heal and reconnenct. Mr. Galford's guidance throughout was invaluable, especially towards graduation. Mike Beswick's ability to get deep into the core issues at the 3-day Parent Program is extraordinary. Having experienced the Parent Program he leads one can easily see why he is a master at what he does. You could literally see how these young women are finally able to understand how their skewed perceptions of themselves are at the core of their struggle. And you could also see how parents are finally able to look deep into themselves and their actions and understand how it affected their children. From day 1 to day 3 the turnaround happening in front of your eyes is magical (of course it takes many months of hard work beforehand). GBA also offers the 'Village' experience where the girls spend time away from the main building looking deep into themselves and their value as human beings. Paul Fowler, the director who runs the Village experience is a most amazing master therapist. My daughter said the most impactful experience she's had at GBA was Village, guided by Paul. She had experienced it 3 times and it was the primary experience that helped her finally realize who she is and believe there is a purpose to her life. GBA parents are also supported and guided by a highly experienced Family Therapist, Greta Lutman, who is very capable at bringing opposing forces - parents who perceive things differently - to work together in an effort to assist their child. With the assistance of all these wonderful people our daughter was able to reconnect with herself and change her misguided perceptions. And we, as parents, were able to better understand each other and our child. It was a remarkable experience that turned our lives around. Our daughter has been home for less than 10 days now and she is submitting her college applications. She is highly motivated and is looking forward to her future - which is so heartwarming. Of course not every girl is able to turn her life around in a short 4-month program. I also cannot pretend that everything at GBA was perfect. I feel the school could benefit from being better organized, especially if a point person could be assigned so parents can bring in non-therapeutic issues and concerns. We had to be persistent and highly involved all along, especially towards graduation. But GBA's ability to tailor specific therapeutic and academic programs to each and every girl is really the basis for its success and maybe a certain level of disorganization is the outcome of that... It's a small price to pay in light of the tremendous success that can be achieved. We are grateful to everyone at the GBA for bringing us our daughter back to us, strong, positive and motivated!

review.author: Sharon C.
review.description: As other reviews have stated, Greenbrier Academy literally saved our daughter's life. A top student and athlete, her life suddenly began to unravel in 9th grade. Psychiatrists, therapists, even hospitalization did nothing to help her. After spending 10 weeks in an outstanding wilderness program (SUWS of the Carolinas), she spent a year at Greenbrier. There aren't enough words to describe the outstanding staff. John Grago, Mike Beswick, Lowell Galford, Kelly Beasley, Rachel Call, LJ, Paul and Greta, Sarah and Angel each played a role in our daughter's transformation, and our family will be forever grateful. The African drumming program, Village, overseas service trip, parent programs and aftercare coaching program are all part of the magic of this very unique and special school. Our daughter is now thriving as a junior in high school and has discovered the lasting treasures of joy, purpose and gratitude. Her experience was so meaningful, she is now looking ahead at becoming a wilderness therapist. I cannot recommend this school highly enough for any family in need of help and healing. Thank you Greenbrier!

review.author: Hil D.
review.description: You child would be better off in a prison.  The show they put on for our tour is NOTHING like the horrific life my daughter suffered there.  As a parent I made a mistake of taking advice from an education consultent and a 8 week program helping my daughter deal with anxiety and depression .  She was NOT at risk for alcohol  or drug abuse . She did not lie or steal and she did not harm herself or anyone else.  I have heard from others that these "Wilderness " programs have ties to theraputic schools.  I am starting to believe this more than ever because her so called "caring " therapist recomended this knowing she was not at high risk.  According to my daughters current therapist she is suffering PTSD because of the trauma she was exposed to at Greenbrier .  PLEASE DO NOT LISTEN TO EDUCATIONAL CONSULTENT or "WILDERNESS PROGRAM " unless you want your daughter to suffer .  I suggest you try everything to find a good theraputic school if you must after trying everything else.  I can tell you Greenbrier is NOT a good one at all. I had a gut instinct to get my daughter out of there before the year .    The food was horrible , verbal and physical assaults by other students  was a reoccuring theme , there is no real education ( be prepared for your daughter to lose a year of proper education ) , theft is as normal as going to the bathroom there ! i forgot to mention for $90,000 a year my daughters therapist was NOT licensed .  This place is a scam and so was the program that ecommended it.  They take advantage of parents that would do anything for their children.  It makes me sick that this DISGUSTING place still operates!!!

review.author: Rick B.
review.description:
Convenient, capable, and friendly - this low-key gunsmith is a retired Army SGM; hats off to him for his service!  I was very happy to find him so nearby.  

Ken is helping me with my AR10, but I'll also use him for inexpensive FFL transfers in the future.  I enjoyed visiting with him, and my wife loved his cute little dog!!

Highly recommended.

review.author: Bill S.
review.description:
Center for Wildlife Education? Do we really need to be educating wildlife? OK, bad joke, and honestly, this is a terrific place that you should go out of your way to visit. In fact, it is quite out of the ordinary, and we think you'll enjoy and learn here. It's located on the Georgia Southern University campus just off Highway 301 south of Statesboro. 

It is primarily a home for birds of prey: falcons, hawks, eagles, owls and the like, some of whom have been injured and are safe only in captivity. They are displayed in a 14-acre woodsy setting that somehow exists in the middle of a very busy urban campus with nearly 20,000 students. You can get up close and personal with an American Bald Eagle, a Snowy Owl (the Harry Potter owl), a Great Horned Owl, a Peregrine Falcon (fastest creature on the planet, capable of flying at 240 mph), etc. These are remarkable birds, and you are quite close to them and can see them fly in daily sessions with trainers. Really impressive, no kidding. The kiddies will love it, and so will mom and dad. There is a winding nature trail that takes you past the bird nests and enclosures as well as wetlands that show other kinds of birds. It's all most attractive and informative, and you can walk it on your own, take a guided tour or get a recorded ipod guide. 

There's a lot more, plenty enough to fill a 2-3 hour visit. It's very cheap: $2 for adults and $1 for kids under 11 and seniors. We recommend a stop; it's about a 20-minute drive from Inerstate-16, so do plan a visit if you're driving between Savannah and Macon. Satisfaction guaranteed.

review.author: Georgia K.
review.description: Fantastic educational spot for adults and children in Statesboro, Georgia. The staff was super knowledgeable as well and were excited to talk to us about the different animals. There's an indoor portion and an outdoor portion - both well laid out and with clear walking paths.

review.author: Cheryl L.
review.description: My first impression of the facility was positive. The receptionist was very friendly and accommodating, the facility was clean. The first exhibit we looked at was indoor with various animals in tanks. It was OK, except for the baby alligators-fairly small aquarium so I asked what happen when they grow? I was informed they swap them out for more babies from a breeder?! That bothered me somewhat. Then, I ventured out to where the raptors are displayed. Upon getting closer to the exhibit, I realized that the raptors were tethered with a maybe 3 inch tether. They kept picking up their feet and tugging at the tether..how is this humane, educational-what message does that send to impressionable young minds? This is a university affiliated center not a sideshow at the circus. I was told they are displayed like that all day. It has haunted me ever since. There has got to be a better way. Why not at least give them some sort of enclosure so they may move around freely all the time? I would not recommend visiting here...unless they choose a more humane way to educate the public.

review.author: Larry L.
review.description: Trillium is a cornerstone of the vibrant arts life in my town, and our family now has its third generation learning and performing with them. Trillium classes are taught by positive, caring and talented artists, both on their stage at the Lewis Theatre and nearby studios,for people age 3-senior adult.  I have taken classes, performed and attended dozens of shows Performances are creative, stimulating and varied, whether a full professional concert or the casual Friday Night Alive! showcases.

name: Twin City Schools Twin City Elementary School

review.author: Austin Elizabeth H.
review.description:
Definitely one of the best schools in the state. If I absolutely had to rank them all on the merit of their academics alone, I'd say #1 tied between Georgia Tech and Emory, #2 UGA, and #3 Georgia Southern.... followed by everywhere else. My sister attended both UGA and GSU though, and told me there was no difference in the quality of the education between them. The school is very progressive-thinking, and the professors tell it like it is, backed by solid science just like any top-notch university. What is different is the culture of these schools.

First off, I am from Statesboro, and initially loathed the idea of going to school in my hometown. I thought that it would be a repeat of high school in south georgia... basically just camo everywhere and a low quality education, and that would be it. I was completely wrong! Sure, there's still a tiny bit of camo (like 4% of students) and some good ol' boys and girls that are really closed-minded, racist, or bland (maybe 15%), but everyone else that goes here is basically the most awesome person that you will ever meet. Those are pretty good statistics, in my opinion. The people here will surprise you. If you never really found your niche anywhere else, my suggestion would be to come to Georgia Southern. The students here are really like family. 

The campus is also absolutely stunning. 90% of the buildings are new construction and totally amazing. The technology here is top notch, in every field. The RAC is amazing, with tons of workout equipment, and gear that you can even rent and take with you! Eagle entertainment offers tons and tons of activities for the students, including de-stressers during exam time (ever wanted to pie someone in the face or smash up an old car?), concerts, food activities, and so much more.

GSU is also located in a quiet town that has a surprising amount of fun things to do and lots of jobs for students. The life in statesboro just can't be beat. The attitude is very much "work hard - play hard." GSU has a notorious party culture, sure, but what can we say? We're high achievers too. I had well above an A average when I graduated, and not for any lack of fun. That's because Georgia Southern is a school of balance. GSU students like to study their behinds off at Henderson library as much as they like relaxing by a pool with a drink in their hands, soaking up the sweet southern sun.

And parents rejoice! The laws will be changing in July of this year, prohibiting all persons under the age of 21 from entering any of the bars, and making it much more difficult for students to drink underage. GSU is also located in a dry county, meaning no liquor is available to be purchased in any store here... and the nearest place to get liquor? Well, it's nearly 45 minutes away - more than far enough to deter most students from going to get it.

As an alumni, I feel really confident saying that Georgia Southern is a special place in this world. It is a lot of fun compared to other colleges, which is something that you should want for yourself if you're considering going here, and for your child if you're a parent. The experiences I had here were once in a lifetime, and I would not trade them for going to any other school. 

There is also something about Georgia Southern that brings students together in a way that I have never seen again anywhere else. Maybe it's because all of the freshmen are required to stay in the dorms together, maybe it's the traditions like FYE, first night out, the lantern walk, etc... we all know each other. We all have been through the same experiences. Eagles love each other, look for each other, and stand by each other when they see another eagle in need. It was a great source of pride for me to have found friends that would stand by my side through anything at this school, and those friendships have remained intact despite the fact that we graduated several years ago.

All-in-all, Georgia Southern is a wonderful school and I'm very proud that I went here for my undergraduate degree. Once an eagle, always an eagle!

review.author: Jenn C.
review.description:
What a BIG campus with some
old southern charm- a few very large & cool live oaks around.

Tour guide was friendly & a student if GA Southern. Tour was 10:30 am - 12:30 pm & ALL WALKING. Not a bad walk, just be prepared.

We were really not able to get to the gym they spoke highly about & we went i to 1 classroom, which was a basic med room.

My daughter wasn't jumping out of her skin in excitement, but she has now a reference to consider.

They have a lot of food options, good parking, seems like nice housing as well.

4 hr drive from Gwinnett county.

I'm sure a fine school! Let's see what comes of today.

review.author: James P.
review.description: If you can't get into a better school, then Southern can be attractive.  Strive for better if you can, this may just be temporary until you get the grades to improve your circumstances.  Take video proof of all your returned assignments so you can calculate your grade at the end of the semester or else you get what you paid for.  The professors here likely make less money than average is my guess.

review.author: Alexander H.
review.description:
Alex Hall
Professor Greene
Composition I
2 July 2015
                                                          Restaurant Review

 Georgia Southern University enrolls thousands of students every year, each of them having their own acquired taste. There are two main eating facilities, the Dining Commons seems to be the favored one. In order to satisfy many different taste buds of students, the variety that they offer is unlimited. They have learned how to make the students feel at home again, by giving them a little taste of it. 
 The identity of the Dining Commons varies in many different ways. They have a variety of choices that fit many cultural backgrounds. Having to capture such a broad audience in the food world their taste has to be indescribable. 
 As you walk in, a sweet face that simply swipes your card and says, "Hope you enjoy." The sweetness and strong smell of coffee fills your lungs. After staying up all night writing papers, this is where students all stop first hoping to get that needed boost of energy. Bright colors hit your eyes as you walk pass, another sweet face greets you at the smoothie station. Students love a refreshing smoothie after soaking up the dreadful heat from the long dreary walks to class. Walking past the smoothie you start to smell the food from the Traditional section, the little salad bar, Signature, the bar that serves a variety of pizza and pasta, Brick Oven, the Backyard Gourmet, and Mongos. 
 The Traditional bar is just like being at home, but they offer more choices. They provide home-cooked meals that bring back memories of grandma's house. The smell of fried chicken and hearing the sizzle of the grease it's just like being at Sunday dinner with my family. They serve things from mashed potatoes, fried chicken, green beans, black-eyed peas, and fried okra. Traditional has to be one of the most favored sections by simply providing the feeling of being at home in your heart. They also serve a nice breakfast. Walking to the back early in the morning smelling fresh bacon, sausage, hot simmering biscuits, two kinds of grits, eggs, and hot pancakes. Nothing feels better than filling up on breakfast right before class.
 The salad bar isn't the most favored by the whole, but the athletes love it. They provide a variety of salad options. Including many different types of lettuce, toppings, fruits, and salad dressing. The sandwich and wrap station is also included in this section. This is set up similar to Subway, providing different choices of bread, meats, toppings, and sauces. Although not many people visit this part of the Dining Commons, when you do your taste buds immediately are satisfied. They also make hot fresh omelets for breakfast if you don't like scrambled eggs from the Traditions, where you get to choose between different cheeses and vegetables to go inside.
 Brick Oven, is like our own pizza joint. There's nothing better than having 7 different kinds of pizza aligned with another table including, bread sticks, and 4 different pastas to choose from. There is also a special dietary section connected called No Whey. Even if you don't like the pasta dishes that they serve, you can instead make your own with separate noodles and a variety of sauces to chose from. These two are the second most favored. Who doesn't like a nice slice of pizza, a quick and easy enough to eat and make it to class in time. It isn't just called Brick Oven because they serve pizza, it's because they actually use a brick oven installed behind the stand. 
 The infamous Gourmet has all things fried and different salads. They provide hot fries, burgers, chicken tenders, onion rings, sweet potato fries, fried chicken sandwiches, chicken salad, crab salad, and potato salad. Being over by the Gourmet makes me think of a hot summer day at a barbeque. The smell of burgers and fresh grilled hotdogs makes my mouth water just thinking about it. They also provide you with so many different sauces, like ketchup, mustard, honey mustard, barbeque sauce, and mayonnaise. 
 Right behind the Gourmet is Mongos, where they have an Asian themed Mongolian grill station with made-to-order dishes. This part of the dining is where you can fresh eggrolls, bourbon chicken, salmon, shrimp, all things teriyaki, and sweet and sour chicken. Right behind this stand there is a big iron stove where they cook your food to your liking. Being in front of this stand is like being at a Miyabi's, if you haven't been to one it's very similar to Mongos. There's nothing like seeing your food being cooked in front of you, and steam reaching the top of the ceiling.
 As you can see the Dinning Commons provides so many different options for everyone. They are able to fill everyone's acquired taste at any given time of day. I would say that their identity is pretty much laid out for them and fits perfectly in Statesboro, Georgia! They definitely deserve a 5 out of 5 stars!

review.author: David G.
review.description: Georgia Southern is an excellent institution of higher learning. I am pursuing an MBA through the Georgia WebMBA program. I am currently in the fourth semester of the five-semester program. The professors are dedicated and knowledgeable. The program staff are friendly and helpful. The entire experience has been outstanding.

review.author: Mel M.
review.description: an awesome university, and many more upgrades and improvements since I graduated.  also, Savannah is near by.  great college for single women....you have the college men and also the surrounding military bases.  this school is set in a sleepy farm town BUT the college is very modern and forward thinking institution and has plentiful activities and a huge international scene.  if you are from up north or a big city- dont be put off by the rural atmosphere surrounding campus.  this university gives the true traditional college experience like on tv. plus there is a shuttle to savannah if you dont have a car- savannah is not huge but they have a very lively weekend club scene.  i was there in the late 90's---it was the BEST experience of my life......i've  been all around the world and USA literally.

review.author: Noah W.
review.description: The food is awful and the pool is closed to everyone except the swim team. The dorms are small and the place place is smelly and dirty.If I could give it less than even zero stars I would.

review.author: Mark D.
review.description:
Now my son went here and he said that the classes were fair if not too hard and that the campus was beautiful and spacious. I appreciated the head heart hand motto of the school because it taught him to love the lord and act on that love. 

He said the surrounding town is smaller than a button and sometimes the folks there give him a weird look because he has blue hair but in general he was treated well. 

The school was very accommodating and helped him go through the trauma of my wife's and my separation. He went through a rough patch and we are so blessed that he had his friends to guide him through this stressful time. They loved the lord and loved him so well and Steven was so good to him, helping him with his studies and just being a shoulder to cry on. 

I cannot stress enough that this school is well worth the money, will teach you to love the lord and your fellow man. In fact we even got to welcome Steven into our family and it was unfortunate that Steven only got to spend 2 years there because he and the staff decided that there was a better place elsewhere for him after the wedding. 

Best 168k we spent on our boys.

review.author: Daniel F.
review.description: This was an solid experience. We had great community during my time there (08-12), and still have some friends to this day from there even though it's 6 hours from my home town. The spiritual emphasis there is unparalleled, as I felt like I was on a spiritual high for much of my time there. Many of the people there love God deeply, and it rubs off. I also loved the area; if you're down for adventure and beautiful scenery and prime locations for finding more to do, NWA is the area to be . Loved it.

review.author: Mckenzie E.
review.description:
If you desire an education that puts Christ at the focal point, then this is the best university I know for you. John Brown chooses professors who desire to teach in a way that will prepare their students to use their gifts to glorify God. They've got the best art program I've ever experienced, and everyone on campus is aware of how important each major is to serve in Gods kingdom and better the world. 
However, if you are a person who wants to party in college, John Brown is not for you. John Brown only requires you to not participate in things like drinking, gambling, premarital sex, or anything that might lead you to participate in those things for the time that you are enrolled at John Brown. 
I've never seen a college like this. Everyone I've talked to who has experienced public colleges says that they are relieved and refreshed by the JBU environment. It's very hard to find a place like this in the US. I've had the best experience. 
If you have any questions message me!

review.author: Polly S.
review.description: Both of our daughters attended JBU and both have nothing negative to say. They thouroughly enjoyed their time there. So much so that when their dad decided to go back for an engineering degree at age 52, there was no other place he would rather be. Their engineering graduates have a 100% job placement rate. The financial aid is top notch. It is a Christian school without the guilt but they do hold the students to a high moral standard. The oldest dorms are under refurbishment right now. The others are standard, basic dorm rooms with everything you need but not fancy. There are some town houses and apartments on campus for upper classmen and many rent apartments off campus. Siloam Springs is a wonderful Christian community. Alcohol sales were just approved a few years ago. Low crime. Nice Hispanic community. Lots of jobs. Beautiful scenery.

review.author: James K.
review.description:
I'm sure that some of my friends would disagree with me, but JBU is a solid institution. Like Rebecca said, it's got it's faults, but it's got it's ups as well.

It's a Christian university, and that can be felt pretty much everywhere on the campus. They're starting to be more open to homosexuals attending the school, but still things like smoking cigarettes/drinking (even if you're of age) will get you into huge trouble. The thing is they have you sign a community covenant at the beginning of each school year, so you're agreeing to the rules. I've been told that if you don't want to abide by the rules, then you don't really need to be attending school here. Makes sense to me.

While it has it's downs the ups far outweigh it. I actually like that they don't allow drinking/parties in the dorms. Don't get me wrong, we still have plenty of laughs and good times, but we also get our work done. If there was alcohol flowing at all times I'm pretty sure there would be a lot less studying going on. 

Overall a great school, and I would recommend it if you're looking for a solid education and don't mind not having a party within spitting distance every night.

Message me if you want more info.

review.author: Nataliya L.
review.description: More downsides than up here, unfortunately. Not worth the price of tuition, especially considering the oppression you'll experience during your time there. Room and board is outrageous even though the dorms are old, less than accommodating, and shabby. A lot of favoritism, so if your parents don't have a building named after them don't get your hopes up on getting anything much out of schooling here. Message me for more information.

review.author: Rebecca G.
review.description: I attended 3 years of college here. It's got it's faults but overall I say my experience was solid. Message me for more detailed questions.

review.author: Karen C.
review.description: I was able to take classes here during the COVID pandemic and it was great because you can take classes remotely. The instructors are knowledgeable and are helpful. They send you a book for whichever class you are taking. You can even retake your classes. And depending on the teacher, the classes are recorded so you can re-watch them. I just wish it was not to the instructor's discretion to record. I wish all the classes could be recorded. However, most of my classes were able to be recorded. CTS is also WIOA verified, which helps with funding for classes if you are able to get unemployment insurance.

review.author: Justin V.
review.description: I took the intermediate and advanced excel classes. I was happy with the coursework, the teacher, the workstation and the information  I learned. I know that my abilities have increased after the class. \n\nMy only contention is that many/most people in the class had overestimated their abilities on excel. This is especially true for the advanced class. I was finished with an entire worksheet while I was waiting for most of the rest of the class to finish the first problem. Essentially, the teacher had no choice but to slow down to the pace of the slowest student while I was chomping at the bit to continue. That's certainly not a knock on the teacher or the education. However, a prerequisite aptitude evaluation would be something to consider.

review.author: Jock B.
review.description: I took beginner class and I use Photoshop Elements. Instructor was very knowledgeable and taught at a great pace that kept everyone and myself on track to become better users of Photoshop.

review.author: Katie A.
review.description: I took the Quickbooks course. I was very impressed with the classroom, teacher, and information. If you chose to take this class request Ms. Sandy! You can tell she really cares about the students, and she tries to make the class work for everyone in their own way. I walked away with two user manuals and a jump drive with everything I did on it!

review.author: Kathy S.
review.description: I have taken Word and Excel classes at CTS and will continue to look into other classes they offer.  I found the instructors very knowledgeable and the small classes allow for the teacher to answer any questions that come up.  I highly recommend CTS.

review.author: kym i.
review.description: I took an Introduction to In Design class for computer graphics software at CTS in Schaumburg because I'm working on a project for my daughters school.  Having no idea what I was getting into with this new software program, I now feel I can navigate my way through the basics.  \nIt was a long day, but the instructor, Chris, kept it casual but informative, gave breaks throughout the day and was very patient with everyone's very elementary skills.  I look forward to finding the time to go back to take the intermediate and advanced courses soon.  It was well worth the time and money well spent.

review.author: Tara N.
review.description: We had a HORRIBLE experience with Midwest Five Star Driving School (aka Midwest Five Star Driving School - Woodstock aka Midwest Five Star Driving School - McHenry.) I have NEVER been so disappointed in a business ever. To embarrass the students by sharing private information in front of the whole class, to teach them about drugs beyond what was technically necessary, to yell at the customer and not listen to the concern of the parent (I preferred NOT to have the male teacher be alone in the car with my daughter on drives, and I wanted to sit in the back of the class room for a few days to make sure we were comfortable with the class) was such a disheartening experience.  It turned out very badly for all involved.\n\nIf you, as a future customer,  would like more information - feel free to reach out to us.  We will be honest and truthful in our experience.

review.author: Kane D.
review.description:
Seeing Erin and going to Crystal Lake Reiki & Acupuncture has changed my life. I always look forward to my reiki sessions with her. At first I didn't know what to expect because I had never even heard of reiki. I was already dabbling in crystals, with sage, and meditation so I was open to the idea of reiki. After the first few sessions I knew that this was something I needed. I never expected what I would take from our sessions, but she has helped me to realize and allow myself to let go, allow myself to heal, love myself, loving others and just understanding more of my spirit and the journey that I am on. 

I also got my first ever acupuncture treatment from her as well. She made sure I was very comfortable because I was nervous about the needles. I had talk about how bad my anxiety was about travel as well as pain in my shins that I've had. We did a treatment right before I went on a trip and it was the best vacation I ever had. I wasn't anxious one bit! There were times I couldn't even go on vacation because my anxiety was crippling or if I made it I was suffering. That trip was amazing, I had moments of anxiety but nothing I couldn't work through. I was also complaining about shin pain as well. I have had shin pain for as long as I can remember for the last 10 years of working in the restaurant buisness. I figured it was just me over working myself, or maybe just too long of a shift that day. I got an acupuncture treatment and I haven't had that pain since. 10/10 high recommend 5 stars 

Erin is amazing at what she does. She's passionate, knowledgeable, hilarious, and comfortable to be around. Making sure that you understand that you as a person are amazing. Thank you for everything that you do, you deserve every bit of praise. May the universe be kind to you

review.author: Britt B.
review.description: I have been seeing Erin for almost two years now maybe longer or at least it feels that way. She's so caring, easy to be around, and informative. My first session I didn't know what to expect but she made the process so easy almost like I was talking with a friend I've known for years. Any judgements about myself, the situation, or doing something new just floated away and I was finally present for myself. I even added acupuncture into my energy sessions which is something I never seen myself doing but she explained everything in detail and eased my mind and it was a beautiful experience. Through this time of knowing Erin we have worked on so many obstacles I felt like I could never tell or come out of. I've seen such a transition in myself that I've been certified through Erin for starting my own energy work journey. I feel like I finally have a way to give back to myself and have UNCONDITIONAL LOVE for myself.  Thank you so much Erin for creating a safe space and having a beautiful soul

review.author: K G.
review.description: My son was very happy with the instruction he received. There were many options for classroom portion ( we needed to do the once a week option). We would recommend

review.author: Heidi H.
review.description: I'm sure many other parents have regretted using this company too. I transferred my daughter and I wish I would have done it sooner. He is happy to take your money but not available for any observation time instead he wants to charge you more for drive time. He is a scam artist and I want buyers to be aware!

review.author: Cristen C.
review.description:
My daughter had a good experience with Top Driver. I brought my son here because the owner's husband/father, a vet, saw one of our horses and she wanted to be sure we knew they had a new driving school.  The husband was nice and very competent so I thought this would be the case in the operation of the driving school It was a newer small business, I decided to invite some other moms to bring their kids to a summer of driving instruction with Janet. It did not go as I had hoped. Listen, these boys are the cream of the crop at school. No trouble, never a detention, never an issue out of any of them and they are also involved in football together. 

Today I had to call the police on Midwest Five Star Driving School after my son was dumped in the dark for not having his permit for an observation, though the owner had a copy.  It was snowing, freezing and her words to him were, "Give me your permit.. Then get out of the car.".   Period. He had no ride, she didnt ask him if he could call his mom, there was no place to wait and it isnt a populated or safe area.  The police had to wait with him while I arranged for emergency transportation. Thank God his phone had a charge.  I feel the school should make arrangements to call a parent in this situation.  My husband is also a vet and owns a small business. I can tell you if we left a client or patient abandoned in a dark parking lot in the snow in winter people would go CRAZY. Why would you do it to a 15 year old boy who lives down the road from you, Janet?  

My son was not happy on nearly every day of class or drives.  My son reported to me that he accidentally hit the gas and lurched the school car forward. He was embarassed and wasnt expecting that and apologized. He was used to driving a more powerful car at home.  His sister drives it to drop him off and he tells me the instructor, Janet, said to him that "Yeah, we all know you drive a truck," as if he was bragging about it which would be out of character and was not his intent. He felt very degraded by Janet Kapraun that day and upset with the way she taught the classes, her interactions with his friends and her attitude toward them.  My son tells me he felt humiliated and degraded and angry when she spoke in certain ways to his friends at class.  I never had these issues at Top Driver.  There are many other Janet-isms to report but I am running out of space. 

This seems to be a mother/son operation. So if you need to complain you could be met with no result which is what occurred with my complaints to their business. The son takes the complaints and was defensive.  The other mothers I took felt the same and I feel embarassed to have recommended Midwest Five Star Driving School owned by Jeff Kapraun and owner or employee Janet Kapraun of Harvard, Illinois. 

I am calling the police department back now...

review.author: Sarah C.
review.description: i love this school more than anything! I've attended west side for the past 13 years of my entire school years. i just graduated this May and I can't even begin to describe how amazing the teachers, staff, coaches and students are! all the teachers want is for you to succeed and they show that very well. i have always felt at home here and will miss it more than anything!

name: Grand Rapids Natural Birth and Pregnancy
